soln_description:
Proof: Let the plane containing $\triangle E F G$ be $\pi$. Without loss of generality, assume the distance from point $B$ to $\pi$ is small. Then, when $B$ does not coincide with $E$, $G^{\prime}$ lies on $A D$. Thus, we have:
$$
E F\left\|B F^{\prime}, E G\right\| B G^{\prime}, F G \| F^{\prime} G^{\prime} \text {. }
$$

Therefore, $\triangle E F G \operatorname{Sos} \triangle B F^{\prime} G^{\prime}$. Clearly, $S \triangle E F G < S \triangle B^{\prime}{ }^{\prime}{ }^{\prime}$:
$$
p \triangle K_{F G} \backslash P \triangle E_{F}{ }^{\prime} G^{\prime} .
$$

Thus, we only need to prove that $\triangle B F^{\prime} G^{\prime}$ satisfies i) and ii). For this, consider the line $F^{\prime} D$. Let the distances from $A, G^{\prime}$, and $D$ to $B F^{\prime}$ be $d_{1}, d_{2}$, and $d_{3}$, respectively. By Lemma 1, we know:
$$
d_{2} \leqslant \max \left\{d_{1}, d_{3}\right\} .
$$
$$
\leqslant \operatorname{mar}\left\{S \triangle A_{D C}, S \triangle E^{\prime} D\right\} \text {. }
$$

Similarly, we can prove:
$$
S \triangle B^{\prime} D_{D} \leqslant \max \{S \triangle A B D, S \triangle B C D\} .
$$

Thus,
$S_{\triangle B F^{\prime} A} \leqslant \operatorname{mad}\{\triangle A B C, S \triangle A B D$,
$S \triangle \triangle C D, S=B C D\}$,
the problem is proved.
Using Lemma 2, we easily get:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
p \Delta B \mathbf{Y}^{\prime}{ }_{G} \leqslant \max \left\{p \Delta A B F{ }_{F}^{\prime}, p \Delta B D F^{\prime}\right\} \\
\leqslant \max \{p \triangle \Delta B C, p \triangle \Delta B D, \\
p \triangle B C D\} \text {. } \\
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $p \Delta B F^{\prime} G^{\prime} \leqslant \max \{p \Delta \triangle B C, p \triangle A B D$, $p \triangle \triangle C D, p \triangle B C D\}$.
Therefore, ii) holds.
informal_statement:
6. Given tetrahedron $ABCD$, points $E, F, G$ are on edges $AB, AC, AD$ respectively. Denote the area of $\triangle XYZ$ as $S_{\triangle XYZ}$ and the perimeter as $p_{\triangle XYZ}$. Prove:
i) $S_{\triangle EFG} \leqslant \max \left\{S_{\triangle ABC}, S_{\triangle ABD}, S_{\triangle ACD}, S_{\triangle BCD}\right\}$,
ii) $p_{\triangle EFG} \leqslant \max \{p_{\triangle ABC}, p_{\triangle ABD}, p_{\triangle ACD}, p_{\triangle BCD}\}$.
Before the proof, we first provide two lemmas.
Lemma 1: Given two lines $l, m$ in space, and points $P, Q, R$ are three consecutive points on $l$, with their distances to $m$ being $d_{1}$, $d_{2}$, $d_{3}$ respectively. Then $d_{2} \leq \max \left\{d_{1}, d_{3}\right\}$.
Proof is omitted.
Lemma 2: Given two lines $l, m$ and two points $M$, $N$ on $l$. Let $P, Q, R$ be three consecutive points on $m$, then $Q M + Q N \leqslant \max \{P M + P N, R M + R N\}$.

Lemma 2 can be simplified by rotating point $N$ around line $m$ into the plane $MPQ$, with $N$ and $M$ on opposite sides of line $m$. The proof is omitted.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- 6. Given tetrahedron $ABCD$, points $E, F, G$ are on edges $AB, AC, AD$ respectively. Denote the area of $\triangle XYZ$ as $S_{\triangle XYZ}$ and the perimeter as $p_{\triangle XYZ}$. Prove:
i) $S_{\triangle EFG} \leqslant \max \left\{S_{\triangle ABC}, S_{\triangle ABD}, S_{\triangle ACD}, S_{\triangle BCD}\right\}$,
ii) $p_{\triangle EFG} \leqslant \max \{p_{\triangle ABC}, p_{\triangle ABD}, p_{\triangle ACD}, p_{\triangle BCD}\}$.
Before the proof, we first provide two lemmas.
Lemma 1: Given two lines $l, m$ in space, and points $P, Q, R$ are three consecutive points on $l$, with their distances to $m$ being $d_{1}$, $d_{2}$, $d_{3}$ respectively. Then $d_{2} \leq \max \left\{d_{1}, d_{3}\right\}$.
Proof is omitted.
Lemma 2: Given two lines $l, m$ and two points $M$, $N$ on $l$. Let $P, Q, R$ be three consecutive points on $m$, then $Q M + Q N \leqslant \max \{P M + P N, R M + R N\}$.

Lemma 2 can be simplified by rotating point $N$ around line $m$ into the plane $MPQ$, with $N$ and $M$ on opposite sides of line $m$. The proof is omitted. -/
theorem inequalities_309304
  (A B C D E F G : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 3))
  (h₀ : E ∈ segment ℝ A B)
  (h₁ : F ∈ segment ℝ A C)
  (h₂ : G ∈ segment ℝ A D)
  (h₃ : SABC = (MeasureTheory.volume (convexHull ℝ {A, B, C})).toReal)
  (h₄ : SABD = (MeasureTheory.volume (convexHull ℝ {A, B, D})).toReal)
  (h₅ : SACD = (MeasureTheory.volume (convexHull ℝ {A, C, D})).toReal)
  (h₆ : SBCD = (MeasureTheory.volume (convexHull ℝ {B, C, D})).toReal)
  (h₇ : pABC = dist A B + dist B C + dist A C)
  (h₈ : pABD = dist A B + dist B D + dist A D)
  (h₉ : pACD = dist A C + dist C D + dist A D)
  (h₁₀ : pBCD = dist B C + dist C D + dist B D) :
  (MeasureTheory.volume (convexHull ℝ {E, F, G})).toReal ≤
  max (max SABC (max SABD SACD)) (SBCD) ∧
  dist E F + dist F G + dist E G ≤
  max (max pABC (max pABD pACD)) (pBCD) :=

soln_description:
Let's prove, when $n \geqslant 2$, we have
$$
a_{n}=4 m+3, m \in \mathbf{N} \text {. }
$$

Using mathematical induction:
(i) When $n=2$, $a_{2}=3^{3}=4 \times 6+3$, so equation (1) holds.
(ii) Assume when $n=k(k \geqslant 2)$, equation (1) holds, i.e.,
$$
a_{k}=4 m+3, m \in \mathbf{N} \text {. }
$$

Then $a_{k+1}=3^{a_{k}}=3^{4 m+3}=(4-1)^{4 m+3}$
$$
\begin{aligned}
= & \mathrm{C}_{4 m+3}^{0} \cdot 4^{4 m+3}(-1)^{0}+\mathrm{C}_{4 m+3}^{1} 4^{4 m+2}(-1)^{1} \\
& +\cdots+\mathrm{C}_{4 m+3}^{4 m+2} 4^{1}(-1)^{4 m+2} \\
& +\mathrm{C}_{4 m+3}^{4 m+3} 4^{0}(-1)^{4 m+3} \\
= & 4 t-1=4(t-1)+3 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, $t=\mathrm{C}_{4 m+3}^{0} 4^{4 m+2}+\mathrm{C}_{4 m+3}^{1} 4^{4 m+1}(-1)^{1}+\cdots+$ $\mathrm{C}_{4 m+3}^{4 m+2}(-1)^{4 m+2}$ is an integer, and since $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ is an increasing sequence, we have $a_{k+1} \geqslant a_{k} \geqslant \cdots \geqslant a_{2}=27$, i.e., $4 t-1 \geqslant 27$. Thus, $t \geqslant 7, t-1 \geqslant 6$, i.e., $t-1 \in \mathbf{N}$.
Therefore, when $n=k+1$, equation (1) holds.
Thus, equation (1) holds, and we have
$$
a_{n}=3^{a_{n-1}}=3^{4 m+3}=(81)^{m} \cdot 27 \text {, }
$$

and its last digit is 7.
informal_statement: Four. (20 points) The sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ is defined as follows: $a_{1}=3, a_{n}=$ $3^{a_{n-1}}(n \geqslant 2)$. Find the last digit of $a_{n}(n \geqslant 2)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Four. (20 points) The sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ is defined as follows: $a_{1}=3, a_{n}=$ $3^{a_{n-1}}(n \geqslant 2)$. Find the last digit of $a_{n}(n \geqslant 2)$. -/
theorem number_theory_301803 (a : ℕ → ℕ) (ha1 : a 1 = 3)
    (han : ∀ n ≥ 2, a n = 3 ^ a (n - 1)) :
    ∀ n ≥ 2, a n % 10 = 7 := by

soln_description:
1. **Substitute \(a, b, c\) with \(x^2, y^2, z^2\):**
   Given \(a = x^2\), \(b = y^2\), and \(c = z^2\), we can rewrite the inequalities:
   \[
   a^2 < 16bc \implies (x^2)^2 < 16(y^2)(z^2) \implies x^4 < 16y^2z^2 \implies x^2 < 4yz \implies x < 2\sqrt{yz}
   \]
   Similarly, we have:
   \[
   y < 2\sqrt{zx} \quad \text{and} \quad z < 2\sqrt{xy}
   \]

2. **Interpret the inequalities geometrically:**
   The inequalities \(x < 2\sqrt{yz}\), \(y < 2\sqrt{zx}\), and \(z < 2\sqrt{xy}\) suggest that \(x, y, z\) can be the lengths of the sides of a triangle. This is because each side length is less than the sum of the other two sides, which is a necessary condition for the sides of a triangle.

3. **Use the triangle inequality:**
   Since \(x, y, z\) are the sides of a triangle, we can use the triangle inequality:
   \[
   x + y > z, \quad y + z > x, \quad \text{and} \quad z + x > y
   \]

4. **Apply Heron's formula:**
   The area \(A\) of a triangle with sides \(x, y, z\) can be given by Heron's formula:
   \[
   A = \sqrt{s(s-x)(s-y)(s-z)}
   \]
   where \(s = \frac{x + y + z}{2}\) is the semi-perimeter of the triangle.

5. **Express the area in terms of \(a, b, c\):**
   The area can also be expressed in terms of \(a, b, c\) as:
   \[
   A = \frac{\sqrt{2(ab + bc + ca) - (a^2 + b^2 + c^2)}}{4}
   \]
   Since the area \(A\) must be positive, we have:
   \[
   \sqrt{2(ab + bc + ca) - (a^2 + b^2 + c^2)} > 0
   \]
   Squaring both sides, we get:
   \[
   2(ab + bc + ca) - (a^2 + b^2 + c^2) > 0
   \]
   Rearranging the terms, we obtain:
   \[
   a^2 + b^2 + c^2 < 2(ab + bc + ca)
   \]

Thus, we have proven the required inequality.

\(\blacksquare\)

The final answer is \( \boxed{ a^2 + b^2 + c^2 < 2(ab + bc + ca) } \)
informal_statement: The positive numbers $a, b, c$ are such that $a^2<16bc, b^2<16ca$ and $c^2<16ab$. Prove that \[a^2+b^2+c^2<2(ab+bc+ca).\]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The positive numbers $a, b, c$ are such that $a^2<16bc, b^2<16ca$ and $c^2<16ab$. Prove that \[a^2+b^2+c^2<2(ab+bc+ca).\] -/
theorem inequalities_54882 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h1 : a ^ 2 < 16 * b * c) (h2 : b ^ 2 < 16 * c * a) (h3 : c ^ 2 < 16 * a * b) :
    a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 + c ^ 2 < 2 * (a * b + b * c + c * a) := by

soln_description:
For $k \geq 0$ we denote $Q_{k}=\frac{X(X-1) \cdots(X-k+1)}{k!}$. Let $n=\operatorname{deg} P$.

$\Rightarrow$ : We will prove by induction on $n$ that $P$ can be written as

$$
\sum_{i=0}^{n} a_{i} Q_{i}
$$

with $a_{0}, \ldots, a_{n}$ being rationals.

- For $n=0$ it is obvious ( $P$ is a constant equal to $a_{0}$ ).
- Suppose the result holds up to $n-1$ for $n \geq 1$. We write $P(X)=Q_{n}(X) U(X)+$ $R(X)$ with $U \in \mathbb{Q}[X]$. By comparing degrees, $U$ must be constant. We then apply the induction hypothesis to $R(X): R=\sum_{i=0}^{\operatorname{deg} R} a_{i} Q_{i}$. We set $a_{n}=U$ and $a_{\operatorname{deg} R+1}, \ldots, a_{n-1}=0$.

We will prove by induction on $k$ that in this decomposition, the $a_{k}$ are integers.

- $a_{0}=P(0) \in \mathbb{Z}$.
- If $a_{0}, \ldots, a_{k-1} \in \mathbb{Z}$, then

$$
a_{k}=\binom{k}{k} a_{k}+\sum_{i=0}^{k-1} a_{i}\binom{k}{i}-\sum_{i=0}^{k-1} a_{i}\binom{k}{i}=P(k)-\sum_{i=0}^{k-1} a_{i}\binom{k}{i} \in \mathbb{Z}
$$

The result follows.

$\Leftarrow:$ We note that we can rewrite the condition as:

$$
P(m)=\sum_{k=0}^{n} a_{k}\binom{m}{k}
$$

and

$$
P(-m)=\sum_{k=0}^{n}(-1)^{k} a_{k}\binom{m+k-1}{k}
$$

for $m \in \mathbb{N}$.

Since the coefficients $a_{i}$ are integers and the binomial coefficients are integers, $P(\mathbb{Z}) \subset \mathbb{Z}$.
informal_statement:
Let $P \in \mathbb{Q}[X]$. Show that $P(\mathbb{Z}) \subset \mathbb{Z}$ if and only if we can write

$$
P(X)=\sum_{k=0}^{n} a_{k} \frac{X(X-1) \cdots(X-k+1)}{k!} \text { with } a_{0}, \ldots, a_{n} \in \mathbb{Z}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $P \in \mathbb{Q}[X]$. Show that $P(\mathbb{Z}) \subset \mathbb{Z}$ if and only if we can write

$$
P(X)=\sum_{k=0}^{n} a_{k} \frac{X(X-1) \cdots(X-k+1)}{k!} \text { with } a_{0}, \ldots, a_{n} \in \mathbb{Z}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_161880 {P : Polynomial ℚ} :
    (∃ f : Polynomial ℤ, ∀ x : ℤ, P.eval (x : ℚ) = f.eval x) ↔
    ∃ n : ℕ, ∃ a : ℕ → ℤ, ∀ x : ℚ, P.eval x = ∑ k in Finset.range (n + 1),
      a k * (∏ i ∈ Finset.range k, (x - i : ℚ)) / Nat.factorial k := by

soln_description:
3. B.

If $\boldsymbol{a}=\left(a_{1}, a_{2}\right) \in M \cap N$, then we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a_{1}=-1+x_{1}=1+2 x_{2}, \\
a_{2}=1+2 x_{1}=-2+3 x_{2} .
\end{array}
$$

Rearranging, we get
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x_{1}-2 x_{2}=2, \\
2 x_{1}-3 x_{2}=-3
\end{array}\right.
$$

Solving, we get $x_{1}=-12, x_{2}=-7$. Therefore, we have
$$
M \cap N=\{(-1-12,1-24)\}=\{(-13,-23)\} \text {. }
$$
informal_statement:
3. Vector Set
$$
\begin{array}{l}
M=\{\boldsymbol{a} \mid \boldsymbol{a}=(-1,1)+x(1,2), x \in \mathbf{R}\}, \\
N=\{\boldsymbol{a} \mid \boldsymbol{a}=(1,-2)+x(2,3), x \in \mathbf{R}\} .
\end{array}
$$

Then $M \cap N=(\quad$.
(A) $\{(1,-2)\}$
(B) $\{(-13,-23)\}$
(C) $\{(-1,1)\}$
(D) $\{(-23,-13)\}$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Set Real

/- 3. Vector Set
$$
\begin{array}{l}
M=\{\boldsymbol{a} \mid \boldsymbol{a}=(-1,1)+x(1,2), x \in \mathbf{R}\}, \\
N=\{\boldsymbol{a} \mid \boldsymbol{a}=(1,-2)+x(2,3), x \in \mathbf{R}\} .
\end{array}
$$

Then $M \cap N=(\quad$.
(A) $\{(1,-2)\}$
(B) $\{(-13,-23)\}$
(C) $\{(-1,1)\}$
(D) $\{(-23,-13)\}$ -/
theorem algebra_301450 {a : ℝ × ℝ}
    (ha : ∃ x, a = (-1, 1) + x * (1, 2)) :
    a ∈ {a | ∃ x, a = (1, -2) + x * (2, 3)} ↔ a = (-13, -23) := by

soln_description:
## Solution

$y^{\prime}=\left(\frac{2}{3} \sqrt{\left(\operatorname{arctg} e^{x}\right)^{3}}\right)^{\prime}=\frac{2}{3} \cdot \frac{3}{2} \cdot \sqrt{\operatorname{arctg} e^{x}} \cdot \frac{1}{1+e^{2 x}} \cdot e^{x}=\frac{e^{x} \cdot \sqrt{\operatorname{arctg} e^{x}}}{1+e^{2 x}}$

## Problem Kuznetsov Differentiation 7-6
informal_statement:
## Task Condition

Find the derivative.

$$
y=\frac{2}{3} \sqrt{\left(\operatorname{arctan} e^{x}\right)^{3}}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- ## Task Condition

Find the derivative.

$$
y=\frac{2}{3} \sqrt{\left(\operatorname{arctan} e^{x}\right)^{3}}
$$ -/
theorem calculus_158413 (y : ℝ → ℝ) (hy : y = fun x => (2/3) * sqrt ((arctan (exp x))^3)) :
    deriv y = fun x => (exp x) * sqrt (arctan (exp x))/(1 + exp (2*x)) := by

soln_description:
2. $\frac{49}{6}$.

Obviously, in all the four-element subsets of set $A$, each element appears 4 times.
Then $\left(a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{5}\right)^{4}=1296 \Rightarrow a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{5}=6$.
Thus, the products of the four elements of set $A$ are 2, 3, $\frac{2}{3}$, 1, $\frac{3}{2}$, and their sum is $\frac{49}{6}$.
informal_statement:
2. Let the set
$$
A=\left\{a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{5}\right\}\left(a_{i} \in \mathbf{R}_{+}, i=1,2, \cdots, 5\right) .
$$

If the set of the products of the four elements in all four-element subsets of set $A$ is $B=\{2,3,4,6,9\}$, then the sum of the elements in set $A$ is $\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. Let the set
$$
A=\left\{a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{5}\right\}\left(a_{i} \in \mathbf{R}_{+}, i=1,2, \cdots, 5\right) .
$$

If the set of the products of the four elements in all four-element subsets of set $A$ is $B=\{2,3,4,6,9\}$, then the sum of the elements in set $A$ is $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_299531 (A : Finset ℝ) (hA : A.card = 5)
    (hA1 : ∀ x ∈ A, x > 0) (hB : {x | ∃ s : Finset ℝ, s ⊆ A ∧ s.card = 4 ∧ x = ∏ i ∈ s, i} = {2, 3, 4, 6, 9}) :
    ∑ x ∈ A, x = 49 / 6 := by

soln_description:
Solution.

The equality

$$
2 \log \frac{a-b}{2}=\log a+\log b-\log 2
$$

can be written in the form

$$
\begin{gathered}
\log \left(\frac{a-b}{2}\right)^{2}=\log \frac{a b}{2}, \quad \text{i.e.} \\
\left(\frac{a-b}{2}\right)^{2}=\frac{a b}{2}
\end{gathered}
$$

from which, by multiplication, we get

$$
a^{2}+b^{2}=4 a b
$$

Now, recall that we are dealing with a right triangle, so $a^{2}+b^{2}=c^{2}$, from which we obtain $c^{2}=4 a b$. Furthermore, since $\sin \alpha=\frac{a}{c}, \cos \alpha=\frac{b}{c}$, we have

$$
4 a b=4 \cdot c \sin \alpha \cdot c \cos \alpha=4 c^{2} \sin \alpha \cdot \cos \alpha
$$

so we can write the last equality in the form

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 4 \sin \alpha \cos \alpha=1 \\
& \text { i.e. } \quad \sin 2 \alpha=\frac{1}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

This implies $2 \alpha=30^{\circ}$ or $2 \alpha=150^{\circ}$, i.e., $\alpha=15^{\circ}$ or $\alpha=75^{\circ}$.

Since $\frac{a-b}{2}>0$ (so that the logarithm at the beginning of the problem is defined), we conclude $a>b$, i.e., $\alpha>\beta=90^{\circ}-\alpha$, so the only solution that fits is

$$
\alpha=75^{\circ}, \beta=15^{\circ}
$$

(5 points)
informal_statement:
2. For the lengths $a, b$ of the legs of a right triangle, it holds that

$$
\log \frac{a-b}{2}=\frac{1}{2}(\log a+\log b-\log 2)
$$

Determine the acute angles of this triangle.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 2. For the lengths $a, b$ of the legs of a right triangle, it holds that

$$
\log \frac{a-b}{2}=\frac{1}{2}(\log a+\log b-\log 2)
$$

Determine the acute angles of this triangle. -/
theorem algebra_231923 (a b : ℝ) (ha : a > 0) (hb : b > 0)
    (h : log ((a - b) / 2) = (log a + log b - log 2) / 2) :
    a = b * tan (75 * π / 180) ∧ b ≠ 0 := by

soln_description:
1. **Claim:** \( abc \ge 27 \)

   **Proof:** 
   By the Arithmetic Mean-Harmonic Mean (AM-HM) inequality, we have:
   \[
   \sqrt[3]{abc} \ge \frac{3}{\frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b} + \frac{1}{c}}
   \]
   Given that \(\frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b} + \frac{1}{c} = 1\), we substitute this into the inequality:
   \[
   \sqrt[3]{abc} \ge \frac{3}{1} = 3
   \]
   Cubing both sides, we get:
   \[
   abc \ge 3^3 = 27
   \]
   This completes the proof of the first claim. \(\blacksquare\)

2. **Claim:** \( a^{a-1} + b^{b-1} + c^{c-1} \ge abc \)

   **Proof:**
   By the Weighted Arithmetic Mean-Geometric Mean (AM-GM) inequality, we have:
   \[
   \left(\frac{1}{a}\right)a^a + \left(\frac{1}{b}\right)b^b + \left(\frac{1}{c}\right)c^c \ge a^{a \cdot \frac{1}{a}} b^{b \cdot \frac{1}{b}} c^{c \cdot \frac{1}{c}}
   \]
   Simplifying the exponents, we get:
   \[
   a^{a \cdot \frac{1}{a}} b^{b \cdot \frac{1}{b}} c^{c \cdot \frac{1}{c}} = abc
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   a^{a-1} + b^{b-1} + c^{c-1} \ge abc
   \]
   Given that \( abc \ge 27 \) from the first claim, we have:
   \[
   a^{a-1} + b^{b-1} + c^{c-1} \ge 27
   \]

3. **Final Step:**
   Multiplying both sides of the inequality \( a^{a-1} + b^{b-1} + c^{c-1} \ge 27 \) by \( abc \), we get:
   \[
   a^a bc + b^b ca + c^c ab \ge 27abc
   \]
   Since \( abc \ge 27 \), we can write:
   \[
   27abc \ge 27(ab + bc + ca)
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   a^a bc + b^b ca + c^c ab \ge 27(ab + bc + ca)
   \]

This completes the proof. \(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
Let $a$, $b$, $c$ be positive reals such that $\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}=1$. Show that $$a^abc+b^bca+c^cab\ge 27bc+27ca+27ab.$$


[i]Proposed by Milan Haiman[/i]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a$, $b$, $c$ be positive reals such that $\frac{1}{a}+\frac{1}{b}+\frac{1}{c}=1$. Show that $$a^abc+b^bca+c^cab\ge 27bc+27ca+27ab.$$


[i]Proposed by Milan Haiman[/i] -/
theorem inequalities_86055 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h : 1 / a + 1 / b + 1 / c = 1) :
    a ^ a * b ^ b * c + b ^ b * c ^ c * a + c ^ c * a ^ a * b ≥
    27 * b * c + 27 * c * a + 27 * a * b := by

soln_description:
We note that $45=3^{2} \cdot 5$ and so $45 k=3^{2} \cdot 5 \cdot k$.

For $45 k$ to be a perfect square, each prime factor has to occur an even number of times. Therefore, $k$ must be divisible by 5 .

We try the smallest two-digit possibilities for $k$ that are divisible by 5 , namely $k=10,15,20, \ldots$

If $k=10$, then $45 k=450$, which is not a perfect square.

If $k=15$, then $45 k=675$, which is not a perfect square.

If $k=20$, then $45 k=900=30^{2}$, which is a perfect square.

Therefore, the smallest two-digit positive integer $k$ for which $45 k$ is a perfect square is $k=20$.
informal_statement: What is the smallest two-digit positive integer $k$ for which the product $45 k$ is a perfect square?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- What is the smallest two-digit positive integer $k$ for which the product $45 k$ is a perfect square? -/
theorem number_theory_288906 :
    IsLeast {k | 10 ≤ k ∧ ∃ m, m^2 = 45 * k} 20 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_288906 :
    IsLeast {k | 10 ≤ k ∧ ∃ m, m^2 = 45 * k} 20 := by
  constructor
  · -- First, let's show 20 is in the set
    constructor
    · norm_num
    · -- Show there exists m such that m^2 = 45 * 20
      use 30
      norm_num
  · -- Now, we need to show that 20 is the smallest such k
    intro k hk
    rcases hk with ⟨hk10, m, hm⟩
    by_contra h
    push_neg at h
    have h1 : k < 20 := h
    have h2 : m ≤ 30 := by nlinarith
    interval_cases k <;> 
      try { 
        interval_cases m <;> omega 
      }

soln_description:
1. **Choose a Prime Number \( p \):**
   Let \( p \) be a prime number such that \( p \geq 1001 \times 2003 \). This ensures that \( p \) is sufficiently large to meet the requirements of the problem.

2. **Define the Set \( S \):**
   Define the set \( S \) as follows:
   \[
   S = \{p, 2p, 3p, \ldots, 2002p\}
   \]
   This set contains 2002 distinct positive integers, each of which is a multiple of \( p \).

3. **Form of Sums of Subsets of \( S \):**
   Consider any subset of \( S \). The sum of the elements of this subset will be of the form:
   \[
   pk
   \]
   where \( k \) is a sum of distinct integers from \( \{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 2002\} \).

4. **Range of \( k \):**
   The maximum value of \( k \) occurs when we sum all elements from 1 to 2002:
   \[
   k \leq 1 + 2 + 3 + \cdots + 2002 = \frac{2002 \times 2003}{2} = 1001 \times 2003
   \]
   Therefore, \( k \) ranges from 1 to \( 1001 \times 2003 \).

5. **Divisibility by \( p \):**
   Since \( p \) is chosen such that \( p \geq 1001 \times 2003 \), \( p \) is greater than any possible value of \( k \). Therefore, \( k \) is not divisible by \( p \).

6. **Perfect Powers:**
   For a sum \( pk \) to be a perfect square, cube, or higher power, \( k \) itself must be a perfect square, cube, or higher power. However, since \( k \) is not divisible by \( p \) and \( p \) is a prime number greater than \( k \), \( k \) cannot be a perfect power.

7. **Conclusion:**
   Since \( k \) cannot be a perfect power, the sum \( pk \) cannot be a perfect square, cube, or higher power.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement: Show that there is a set of $2002$ distinct positive integers such that the sum of one or more elements of the set is never a square, cube, or higher power.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Show that there is a set of $2002$ distinct positive integers such that the sum of one or more elements of the set is never a square, cube, or higher power. -/
theorem number_theory_36287 :
    ∃ s : Finset ℕ, s.card = 2002 ∧ ∀ t ⊆ s, ∀ n ∈ t, n > 0 ∧ ¬∃ k : ℕ, k > 0 ∧ ∑ i ∈ t, i = k ^ 2 ∨ ∑ i ∈ t, i = k ^ 3 ∨ ∑ i ∈ t, i = k ^ (k + 1) := by

soln_description:
2. Given that $f(x)=x$ has no real roots, therefore, when $a>0$, for all real numbers $x$ we have $f(x)>x$, thus, $f(f(x))>f(x)>x$. Hence, when $a>0$, the equation $f(f(x))=x$ has no real roots.

Similarly, when $a<0$, we get $f(x)<x$, thus $f(f(x))<f(x)<x$, so when $a<0$, the equation $f(f(x))=x$ also has no real roots.
Given that $f(x)$ is a quadratic polynomial, i.e., $a \neq 0$, the proposition is proved.
informal_statement:
2. Given the quadratic trinomial $f(x)=a x^{2}+b x+c$ such that the equation $f(x)=x$ has no real roots. Prove: The equation $f(f(x))=x$ also has no real roots.
(7th All-Soviet Union Olympiad)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. Given the quadratic trinomial $f(x)=a x^{2}+b x+c$ such that the equation $f(x)=x$ has no real roots. Prove: The equation $f(f(x))=x$ also has no real roots.
(7th All-Soviet Union Olympiad) -/
theorem algebra_188141 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (hf : ∀ x, f x ≠ x) (a b c : ℝ)
    (ha : a ≠ 0) (h : ∀ x, f x = a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c) :
    ∀ x, f (f x) ≠ x := by

informal_statement: Given ten distinct real numbers $x_1, x_2, \dots, x_{10}$, a number $x_i$ is underlined if it is equal to the product of the other nine numbers. Determine the maximum number of distinct numbers that can be underlined.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Given ten distinct real numbers $x_1, x_2, \dots, x_{10}$, a number $x_i$ is underlined if it is equal to the product of the other nine numbers. Determine the maximum number of distinct numbers that can be underlined. -/
theorem algebra_6762 (x : Fin 10 → ℝ) (hx : ∀ i, x i ≠ 0)
    (hxi : ∀ i j, i ≠ j → x i ≠ x j) :
    {i | x i = ∏ j : Fin 10, if j ≠ i then x j else 1}.encard ≤ 2 := by

soln_description:
【Analysis】$\overline{m 0 A 0 B 9 C}$ is a multiple of 33, i.e., $m+A+B+\overline{9 C}=90+m+A+B+C$ is a multiple of 33 when $m=2$, $92+A+B+C$ is a multiple of 33, since $92+A+B+C \leq 92+27=119$, so $92+A+B+C=99, A+B+C=7$, i.e., $(A+1)+(B+1)+(C+1)=10$, by the stars and bars method, there are $C_{9}^{2}=36$ numbers that meet the requirement, i.e., $a_{2}=36$

When $m=3$, $93+A+B+C$ is a multiple of 33, since $93+A+B+C \leq 93+27=120$, so $93+A+B+C=99, A+B+C=6$, i.e., $(A+1)+(B+1)+(C+1)=9$, by the stars and bars method, there are $C_{8}^{2}=28$ numbers that meet the requirement, i.e., $a_{3}=28$ thus $a_{2}-a_{3}=8$
informal_statement: 16. A seven-digit number $\overline{m 0 A 0 B 9 C}$ is a multiple of 33. We denote the number of such seven-digit numbers as $a_{m}$. For example, $a_{5}$ represents the number of seven-digit numbers of the form $\overline{50 A 0 B 9 C}$ that are multiples of $\mathbf{3 3}$. Then $a_{2}-a_{3}=$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 16. A seven-digit number $\overline{m 0 A 0 B 9 C}$ is a multiple of 33. We denote the number of such seven-digit numbers as $a_{m}$. For example, $a_{5}$ represents the number of seven-digit numbers of the form $\overline{50 A 0 B 9 C}$ that are multiples of $\mathbf{3 3}$. Then $a_{2}-a_{3}=$ -/
theorem number_theory_112546 (a : ℕ → ℕ) (ha : ∀ m, a m = {n | n ∈ Finset.Icc 1000000 9999999 ∧ n % 33 = 0 ∧ (n / 1000000) % 10 = m ∧ (n / 100000) % 10 = 0 ∧ (n / 10000) % 10 = B ∧ (n / 1000) % 10 = 9 ∧ (n / 100) % 10 = C}.ncard) :
    a 2 - a 3 = 8 := by

soln_description:
Solution. There are two cases possible.

Case 1. Suppose that $a b c d \geqslant 16$. Then, by the inequality between the quadratic mean and the arithmetic mean, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}+ & d^{2} \geqslant 4\left(\frac{a+b+c+d}{4}\right)^{2} \geqslant \\
& \geqslant 4\left(\frac{a b c d}{8}\right)^{2}=\frac{(a b c d)^{2}}{16} \geqslant a b c d
\end{aligned}
$$

which is what we needed to prove.

Case 2. Now let $a b c d < 16$. Then we have $\sqrt{a^{2} b^{2} c^{2} d^{2}}=a b c d$, which is what we needed to prove.

Remark. The statement of the problem remains true for arbitrary (not necessarily positive) real numbers $a, b, c, d$.
informal_statement:
11.6. Positive numbers $a, b, c$ and $d$ satisfy the condition $2(a + b + c + d) \geqslant a b c d$. Prove that $a^{2} + b^{2} + c^{2} + d^{2} \geqslant a b c d$.

(A. Khryabrov)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 11.6. Positive numbers $a, b, c$ and $d$ satisfy the condition $2(a + b + c + d) \geqslant a b c d$. Prove that $a^{2} + b^{2} + c^{2} + d^{2} \geqslant a b c d$.

(A. Khryabrov) -/
theorem inequalities_157789 (a b c d : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) (hd : 0 < d)
    (h : 2 * (a + b + c + d) ≥ a * b * c * d) :
    a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 + c ^ 2 + d ^ 2 ≥ a * b * c * d := by

soln_description:
Answer: $(1 ; 6),(14 ; 13)$.

Solution: The original equation can be represented as

$$
2 y^{2}-x y-x^{2}+2 y+7 x-12=72
$$

Next, we factorize the left side of the equation using the discriminant:

$$
(x+2 y-4)(y-x+3)=72
$$

Since $72=1 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 3$, we can reduce the number of cases to check.

Let $x+2 y-4=a, y-x+3=b$. Then $a \cdot b=72$ and $y=\frac{a+b+1}{3}$ and $y \in \mathbb{N}$.

Therefore, $a$ and $b$ cannot be negative, and neither of them should be divisible by 3, but one of them must be divisible by 9. Thus, we reduce the number of cases to:

1) $\left\{\begin{array}{l}a=9, \\ b=8 .\end{array}\right.$ 2) $\left\{\begin{array}{l}a=8, \\ b=9 .\end{array}\right.$, $)\left(\begin{array}{l}a=18, \\ b=4 .\end{array}\right.$ 4) $\left\{\begin{array}{l}a=4, \\ b=18 .\end{array}\right.$ ) $)\left\{\begin{array}{l}a=36, \\ b=2 .\end{array}\right.$, $\left\{\begin{array}{l}a=2, \\ b=36 .\end{array}\right.$ 7) $\left\{\begin{array}{c}a=72, \\ b=1 .\end{array},\left\{\begin{array}{l}a=1, \\ b=72 .\end{array}\right.\right.$ Considering $y=\frac{a+b+1}{3}, y \in \mathbb{N}$, we find that only two cases fit:

$$
\text { 1) }\left\{\begin{array} { l } 
{ a = 9 , } \\
{ b = 8 }
\end{array} \text { 2) } \left\{\begin{array}{c}
a=36 \\
b=2
\end{array}\right.\right.
$$

From this, we obtain two solutions: $(\mathbf{1} ; \mathbf{6}),(\mathbf{1 4} ; \mathbf{1 3})$.
informal_statement:
1. Solve the equation in natural numbers

$$
2 y^{2}-x y-x^{2}+2 y+7 x-84=0
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Solve the equation in natural numbers

$$
2 y^{2}-x y-x^{2}+2 y+7 x-84=0
$$ -/
theorem algebra_234078 (x y : ℕ) :
    2*y^2 - x*y - x^2 + 2*y + 7*x - 84 = 0 ↔ (x=1 ∧ y=6) ∨ (x=14 ∧ y=13) := by

informal_statement: Postive real numbers $a, b, c$ satisfy $abc=1$. Show that $$\frac{a^3+a^2}{1+bc}+\frac{b^3+b^2}{1+ca}+\frac{c^3+c^2}{1+ab}\geq3.$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Postive real numbers $a, b, c$ satisfy $abc=1$. Show that $$\frac{a^3+a^2}{1+bc}+\frac{b^3+b^2}{1+ca}+\frac{c^3+c^2}{1+ab}\geq3.$$ -/
theorem inequalities_49171 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (habc : a * b * c = 1) :
    3 ≤ (a ^ 3 + a ^ 2) / (1 + b * c) + (b ^ 3 + b ^ 2) / (1 + c * a) +
        (c ^ 3 + c ^ 2) / (1 + a * b) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_49171 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (habc : a * b * c = 1) :
    3 ≤ (a ^ 3 + a ^ 2) / (1 + b * c) + (b ^ 3 + b ^ 2) / (1 + c * a) +
        (c ^ 3 + c ^ 2) / (1 + a * b) := by
  
  have h1 : 1 + b * c = (a + 1) / a := by
    field_simp
    nlinarith [habc]

  have h2 : 1 + c * a = (b + 1) / b := by
    field_simp
    nlinarith [habc]

  have h3 : 1 + a * b = (c + 1) / c := by
    field_simp
    nlinarith [habc]

  have h4 : (a ^ 3 + a ^ 2) / (1 + b * c) = a ^ 3 := by 
    rw [h1]
    field_simp
    <;> nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - 1), sq_nonneg (b - 1), sq_nonneg (c - 1)]

  have h5 : (b ^ 3 + b ^ 2) / (1 + c * a) = b ^ 3 := by 
    rw [h2]
    field_simp
    <;> nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - 1), sq_nonneg (b - 1), sq_nonneg (c - 1)]

  have h6 : (c ^ 3 + c ^ 2) / (1 + a * b) = c ^ 3 := by 
    rw [h3]
    field_simp
    <;> nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - 1), sq_nonneg (b - 1), sq_nonneg (c - 1)]
  
  have h12 : (a ^ 3 + a ^ 2) / (1 + b * c) + (b ^ 3 + b ^ 2) / (1 + c * a) + (c ^ 3 + c ^ 2) / (1 + a * b) = a ^ 3 + b ^ 3 + c ^ 3 := by
    rw [h4, h5, h6]
  
  have h7 : a ^ 3 + b ^ 3 + c ^ 3 ≥ 3 := by 
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (b - c), sq_nonneg (c - a),
      sq_nonneg (a + b + c - 3), sq_nonneg (a * b - 1), sq_nonneg (b * c - 1), sq_nonneg (c * a - 1),
      mul_pos ha hb, mul_pos hb hc, mul_pos ha hc]

  linarith [h12, h7]

soln_description: [Solution] When $a=-6$, the original equation becomes $x^{2}-1=0$, yielding $x= \pm 1$. When $a \neq-6$, and $a \in \mathbb{Z}$, the original equation has no integer roots. Therefore, the answer is $(A)$.
informal_statement:
$31 \cdot 16$ When $a \in Z$, the number of integer solutions for the equation $a x^{2}+6=0$ with respect to $x$ is
(A) 0 or 2.
(B) 0 or 1 or 2.
(C) 2.
(D) 1 or 2.
(2nd "Hope Cup" National Mathematics Invitational Competition, 1991)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- $31 \cdot 16$ When $a \in Z$, the number of integer solutions for the equation $a x^{2}+6=0$ with respect to $x$ is
(A) 0 or 2.
(B) 0 or 1 or 2.
(C) 2.
(D) 1 or 2.
(2nd "Hope Cup" National Mathematics Invitational Competition, 1991) -/
theorem algebra_235354 (a : ℤ) :
    Set.ncard {x : ℤ | a * x ^ 2 + 6 = 0} = 0 ∨ Set.ncard {x : ℤ | a * x ^ 2 + 6 = 0} = 2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_235354 (a : ℤ) :
    Set.ncard {x : ℤ | a * x ^ 2 + 6 = 0} = 0 ∨ Set.ncard {x : ℤ | a * x ^ 2 + 6 = 0} = 2 := by

  have h1 : {x : ℤ | a * x ^ 2 + 6 = 0} = (∅ : Set ℤ) ∨ {x : ℤ | a * x ^ 2 + 6 = 0} = {1, -1} := by
    by_cases h : a = -6
    · -- case a = -6
      have eq : {x : ℤ | a * x ^ 2 + 6 = 0} = {1, -1} := by
        ext x
        simp [h]
        constructor
        · intro h_eq
          have h1 : x^2 = 1 := by linarith
          have : x = 1 ∨ x = -1 := by
            rw [sq_eq_one_iff] at h1
            exact h1
          tauto
        · rintro (rfl | rfl)
          · norm_num
          · norm_num
      right
      exact eq
    · -- a ≠ -6
      have h2 : ∀ x : ℤ, ¬ (a * x ^ 2 + 6 = 0) := by
        intro x
        intro h_eq
        have h3 : a * x ^ 2 = -6 := by linarith
        have h4 : x^2 ≥ 0 := by nlinarith
        have h5 : a < 0 := by nlinarith
        have h6 : x^2 ≤ 6 := by
          nlinarith [show a * x ^ 2 > -7 by omega]
        have h9 : x ≤ 2 := by nlinarith [show x^2 ≥ 0 by nlinarith]
        have h10 : x ≥ -2 := by nlinarith [show x^2 ≥ 0 by nlinarith]
        interval_cases x <;> omega
      have eq1 : {x : ℤ | a * x ^ 2 + 6 = 0} = ∅ := by
        ext x
        simp [h2]
      left
      exact eq1

  rcases h1 with (h_eq | h_eq)
  · -- case empty set
    rw [h_eq]
    simp
  · -- case {1, -1}
    rw [h_eq]
    simp [Set.ncard_pair]
    <;> try { try omega }

soln_description:
Solution. The given homogeneous figure is symmetric with respect to the bisector of the first coordinate angle (Fig. 127), therefore $x_{c}=y_{c}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_8a069bcd8684ea7ea3dbg-224.jpg?height=169&width=518&top_left_y=342&top_left_x=146)

Fig. 126

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_8a069bcd8684ea7ea3dbg-224.jpg?height=323&width=334&top_left_y=191&top_left_x=764)

Fig. 127

Let's compute the integrals contained in the first 113 formulas (2):

$$
\begin{aligned}
& I_{1}=\int_{a}^{b} x y d x=\int_{0}^{a} x\left(a^{\frac{1}{2}}-x^{\frac{1}{2}}\right)^{2} d x=\int_{0}^{a}\left(a x-2 a^{\frac{1}{2}} x^{\frac{3}{2}}+x^{2}\right) d x= \\
& =\left.\left(\frac{1}{2} a x^{2}-\frac{4}{5} a^{\frac{1}{2}} x^{\frac{b}{2}}+\frac{1}{3} x^{3}\right)\right|_{0} ^{a}=\frac{a^{3}}{30} \\
& I_{2}=\int_{a}^{b} y d x=\int_{0}^{a}\left(a^{\frac{1}{2}}-x^{\frac{1}{2}}\right)^{2} d x=\int_{0}^{a}\left(a-2 a^{-\frac{1}{2}} x^{\frac{1}{2}}+x\right) d x=\frac{a^{2}}{6}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $x_{C}=y_{C}=\frac{l_{1}}{I_{2}}=\frac{a}{5}$.
informal_statement: 682. Find the center of gravity of a homogeneous figure (plate) bounded by the parabola $\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{y}=\sqrt{a}$ and the coordinate axes.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 682. Find the center of gravity of a homogeneous figure (plate) bounded by the parabola $\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{y}=\sqrt{a}$ and the coordinate axes. -/
theorem calculus_185611 {a : ℝ} (ha : a > 0) :
    let x := ∫ x in (0)..a, x * sqrt (a - x) / (a * (a - x))
    let y := ∫ y in (0)..a, y * sqrt (a - y) / (a * (a - y))
    x = y := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

theorem calculus_185611 {a : ℝ} (ha : a > 0) :
    let x := ∫ x in (0)..a, x * sqrt (a - x) / (a * (a - x))
    let y := ∫ y in (0)..a, y * sqrt (a - y) / (a * (a - y))
    x = y := by 
  simp 
  all_goals 
    norm_num
    <;> try { ring_nf <;> norm_num }

soln_description:
3. $k=1$.

Let $2=p_{1}1, k>1$.
Since $a$ is odd and coprime with $p_{i}(1 \leqslant i \leqslant k)$, we know $a>p_{k}$.
Without loss of generality, we can assume $n$ is a prime (if $n=s t$, then we can replace $n$ with $t$ and $a$ with $a^{2}$).
Since $a^{2}+1$ is not a multiple of 3, we have $n>2$.
If there exists $2 \leqslant i \leqslant k, n=p_{i}$, then $p_{i} \mid\left(a^{p_{i}}+1\right)$.
On the other hand, by Fermat's Little Theorem, we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a^{p_{i}} \equiv a\left(\bmod p_{i}\right) \Rightarrow p_{i} \mid(a+1) \\
\Rightarrow a \equiv-1\left(\bmod p_{i}\right) \\
\Rightarrow 1-a+a^{2}-\cdots+a^{p_{i}-1} \\
\quad \equiv \underbrace{1+1+\cdots+1}_{p_{i} \uparrow}=p_{i} \equiv 0\left(\bmod p_{i}\right) .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $p_{1} p_{2} \cdots p_{k}=a^{p_{i}}+1$
$$
=(a+1)\left(1-a+a^{2}-\cdots+a^{p_{i}-1}\right)
$$

is a multiple of $p_{i}^{2}$, which is a contradiction.
Therefore, $a>p_{k}$.
Then $a^{n}+1>p_{k}^{p_{k}}>p_{k}^{k}>p_{1} p_{2} \cdots p_{k}$, which is a contradiction.
informal_statement: 3. Find all positive integers $k$ such that the product of the first $k$ primes minus 1 is a positive integer that is a perfect power greater than 1.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. Find all positive integers $k$ such that the product of the first $k$ primes minus 1 is a positive integer that is a perfect power greater than 1. -/
theorem number_theory_315203 (k : ℕ) :
    k > 0 ∧ ∃ m, m > 0 ∧ (∏ i ∈ Finset.range k, (Nat.nth {p | p.Prime} i)) - 1 = m ^ n ∧ n > 1 ↔ k = 1 := by

soln_description:
Solution:
Since $\cos \gamma=-\cos (\alpha+\beta)=-\cos \alpha \cos \beta+\sin \alpha \sin \beta$, and $\cos (\alpha-\beta)=\cos \alpha \cos \beta+\sin \alpha \sin \beta$ the given inequality transforms to
$$
\begin{array}{r}
\frac{\sin \beta \sin \gamma-\cos \beta \cos \gamma}{\sin \beta \sin \gamma+\cos \beta \cos \gamma}+\frac{\sin \gamma \sin \alpha-\cos \gamma \cos \alpha}{\sin \gamma \sin \alpha+\cos \gamma \cos \alpha} \\
+\frac{\sin \alpha \sin \beta-\cos \alpha \cos \beta}{\sin \alpha \sin \beta+\cos \alpha \cos \beta} \geq \frac{3}{2} \\
\frac{\tan \beta \tan \gamma-1}{\tan \beta \tan \gamma+1}+\frac{\tan \gamma \tan \alpha-1}{\tan \gamma \tan \alpha+1}+\frac{\tan \alpha \tan \beta-1}{\tan \alpha \tan \beta+1} \geq \frac{3}{2} .
\end{array}
$$

Some elementary trigonometry yields
$$
\begin{aligned}
\tan \alpha+\tan \beta+\tan \gamma & =\frac{\sin \alpha \cos \beta \cos \gamma+\sin \beta \cos \alpha \cos \gamma+\sin \gamma \cos \alpha \cos \beta}{\cos \alpha \cos \beta \cos \gamma} \\
& =\frac{\sin \alpha \cos \beta \cos \gamma+\cos \alpha(\sin \beta \cos \gamma+\sin \gamma \cos \beta)}{\cos \alpha \cos \beta \cos \gamma} \\
& =\frac{\sin \alpha \cos \beta \cos \gamma+\cos \alpha \sin (\beta+\gamma)}{\cos \alpha \cos \beta \cos \gamma}
\end{aligned}
$$

Now we use the fact that the angles add to $180^{\circ}$ to see that $\sin (\beta+\gamma)=\sin (\alpha)$, so
$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\sin \alpha \cos \beta \cos \gamma+\cos \alpha \sin (\beta+\gamma)}{\cos \alpha \cos \beta \cos \gamma} & =\frac{\sin \alpha \cos \beta \cos \gamma+\cos \alpha \sin \alpha}{\cos \alpha \cos \beta \cos \gamma} \\
& =\frac{\sin \alpha \cdot(\cos \beta \cos \gamma+\cos \alpha)}{\cos \alpha \cos \beta \cos \gamma} \\
& =\frac{\sin \alpha \cdot(\cos \beta \cos \gamma-\cos (\beta+\gamma))}{\cos \alpha \cos \beta \cos \gamma} \\
& =\frac{\sin \alpha \cdot(\cos \beta \cos \gamma-(\cos \beta \cos \gamma-\sin \beta \sin \gamma))}{\cos \alpha \cos \beta \cos \gamma} \\
& =\tan \alpha \tan \beta \tan \gamma .
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, setting $x=\tan \alpha$ and so on, our inequality
$$
\frac{y z-1}{y z+1}+\frac{z x-1}{z x+1}+\frac{x y-1}{x y+1} \geq \frac{3}{2}
$$
has the property that $x, y, z$ are positive real numbers satisfying $x+y+z=x y z$.
Multiplying the numerator and the denominator of the first fraction by $x$, second by $y$ and third by $z$ the inequality becomes
$$
\frac{S-x}{S+x}+\frac{S-y}{S+y}+\frac{S-z}{S+z} \geq \frac{3}{2},
$$
for $S=x y z$. Using the substitution $S+x=a, S+y=b, S+z=c$ and solving for $S, x, y, z$ we get $S=\frac{a+b+c}{4}$, $x=\frac{3 a-b-c}{4}, y=\frac{3 b-a-c}{4}, z=\frac{3 c-a-b}{4}, S-x=\frac{b+c-a}{2}, S-y=\frac{c+a-b}{2}, S-z=\frac{a+b-c}{2}$, and (1) becomes
$$
\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{b}{a}+\frac{c}{a}-1+\frac{a}{b}+\frac{c}{b}-1+\frac{a}{c}+\frac{b}{c}-1\right) \geq \frac{3}{2} .
$$

This immediately follows from $\frac{b}{a}+\frac{a}{b} \geq 2, \frac{a}{c}+\frac{c}{a} \geq 2$, and $\frac{c}{b}+\frac{b}{c} \geq 2$.
Remark. Once the inequality is transformed to (1) we can use the convexity of the function $f(t)=\frac{S-t}{S+t}$ and Jensen's inequality:
$$
\frac{1}{3}(f(x)+f(y)+f(z)) \geq f\left(\frac{x+y+z}{3}\right) .
$$

It can be easily seen that the previous inequality is exactly (1).
Solution 2, earning a Brilliancy award for Amol Aggarwal of Saratoga HS:
Let $O$ be the circumcenter of $\triangle A B C$. Extend $A O$ to meet $B C$ at $X$, and similarly $B O$ extends to $Y$ and $C O$ to $Z$. As shown in the diagram at left below, draw $A A^{\prime}$ parallel to $B C$, drop the altitude $A H$ from point $A$, and also draw $M O$, the perpendicular bisector of $B C$, meeting $A A^{\prime}$ at $N$.
Now $A H M N$ is a rectangle, so $A H=M N$. Also, $A B C A^{\prime}$ is a cyclic trapezoid and thus isosceles, so $\angle A^{\prime} B C=$ $\angle A C B=\gamma$. Thus $\angle A B A^{\prime}=\angle A B C=\angle A C B=\beta-\gamma$, so the measure of arc $A A^{\prime}=2(\beta-\gamma)$, which means that $\angle A O N=\beta-\gamma$. Using right triangle $O N A$, we have $O N=O A \cos (\beta-\gamma)$.
Again using central and inscribed angles, arc $B C=2 \alpha$ so $\angle B O M=\alpha$ and $O M=O B \cos \alpha$. Dividing $O M$ by $O N$,
$$
\frac{O M}{O N}=\frac{O B \cos \alpha}{O A \cos (\beta-\gamma)}=\frac{\cos \alpha}{\cos (\beta-\gamma)} \text {. }
$$

Finally, because $A A^{\prime} \| B C, \triangle A N O \sim \triangle X M O$, which gives $\frac{O X}{O A}=\frac{O M}{O N}$.
Now by symmetry, we can find similar relationships for all three fractions in the original inequality, so our goal now is to prove that
$$
\frac{O X}{O A}+\frac{O Y}{O B}+\frac{O Z}{O C} \geq \frac{3}{2} .
$$

In the figure at right above, the area ratio $\frac{A O}{A X}=\frac{[A B O C]}{[A B C]}$, so adding analogous terms for each of the three ratios,
$$
\frac{A O}{A X}+\frac{B O}{B Y}+\frac{C O}{C Z}=\frac{[A B O C]+[B C O A]+[A O B C]}{[A B C]}=2,
$$
since the numerator counts the area of each piece exactly twice.
Next, by the arithmetic mean - harmonic mean inequality (or Cauchy-Schwarz if you prefer),
$$
\left(\frac{A O}{A X}+\frac{B O}{B Y}+\frac{C O}{C Z}\right)\left(\frac{A X}{A O}+\frac{B Y}{B O}+\frac{C Z}{C O}\right) \geq 9 .
$$

Finally, since $\frac{A X}{A O}=1+\frac{O X}{A O}$ and similarly for the other two fractions, we can first divide by 2 and then subtract 3 from each side,
$$
\frac{O X}{O A}+\frac{O Y}{O B}+\frac{O Z}{O C} \geq \frac{9}{2}-3=\frac{3}{2} .
$$
informal_statement:
7 Let $\triangle A B C$ be an acute triangle with angles $\alpha, \beta$, and $\gamma$. Prove that
$$
\frac{\cos \alpha}{\cos (\beta-\gamma)}+\frac{\cos \beta}{\cos (\gamma-\alpha)}+\frac{\cos \gamma}{\cos (\alpha-\beta)} \geq \frac{3}{2} .
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- 7 Let $\triangle A B C$ be an acute triangle with angles $\alpha, \beta$, and $\gamma$. Prove that
$$
\frac{\cos \alpha}{\cos (\beta-\gamma)}+\frac{\cos \beta}{\cos (\gamma-\alpha)}+\frac{\cos \gamma}{\cos (\alpha-\beta)} \geq \frac{3}{2} .
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_269460 (α β γ : Real) (h₀ : α ∈ Ioo 0 (π / 2)) (h₁ : β ∈ Ioo 0 (π / 2))
    (h₂ : γ ∈ Ioo 0 (π / 2)) (h₃ : α + β + γ = π) :
    3 / 2 ≤ cos α / cos (β - γ) + cos β / cos (γ - α) + cos γ / cos (α - β) := by

informal_statement: 6. Let the non-real complex number $z$, satisfy $z^{23}=1$. Then $\sum_{k=0}^{22} \frac{1}{1+z^{k}+z^{2 k}}=$

import Mathlib

/- 6. Let the non-real complex number $z$, satisfy $z^{23}=1$. Then $\sum_{k=0}^{22} \frac{1}{1+z^{k}+z^{2 k}}=$ -/
theorem algebra_304850 (z : ℂ) (hz : z ^ 23 = 1) (hzr : z.im ≠ 0) :
    ∑ k in Finset.range 23, 1 / (1 + z ^ k + z ^ (2 * k)) = 46 / 3 := by

soln_description:
2. Solution. The sum of the digits of number $A$ and the numbers obtained from $A$ by cyclic permutations of its digits is $a+b+17$. After summing these numbers (there are 6 of them), in each digit place of number $B$ we get

$a+b+17$, so $B=(a+b+17)\left(10^{5}+10^{4}+10^{3}+10^{2}+10+1\right)=(a+b+17) \cdot 111111$. Since

$111111=3 \cdot 7 \cdot 11 \cdot 13 \cdot 37$, $B$ is divisible by 121 if and only if $a+b+17$ is divisible by 11. Since $a$ and $b$ are digits, there are only two possible cases: $a+b=5$ and $a+b=16$. From this, we find the possible pairs of $a$ and $b$: $a=1, b=4 ; a=2, b=3 ; a=3, b=2 ; a=4, b=1 ; a=7, b=9 ; a=8, b=8 ; a=9, b=7$. Thus, 7 numbers satisfy the condition of the problem. The largest number is obtained when $a=9, b=7$. It is 796317.
informal_statement: 2. The number $A$ in decimal form is represented as $A=\overline{7 a 631 b}$, where $a, b$ are non-zero digits. The number $B$ is obtained by summing all distinct six-digit numbers, including $A$, that are formed by cyclic permutations of the digits of $A$ (the first digit moves to the second position, the second to the third, and so on, with the last digit moving to the first position). How many numbers $A$ exist such that $B$ is divisible by 121? Find the largest such $A$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. The number $A$ in decimal form is represented as $A=\overline{7 a 631 b}$, where $a, b$ are non-zero digits. The number $B$ is obtained by summing all distinct six-digit numbers, including $A$, that are formed by cyclic permutations of the digits of $A$ (the first digit moves to the second position, the second to the third, and so on, with the last digit moving to the first position). How many numbers $A$ exist such that $B$ is divisible by 121? Find the largest such $A$. -/
theorem number_theory_134034 :
    IsGreatest {A | ∃ a b : ℕ, a ≠ 0 ∧ b ≠ 0 ∧ A = 700000 + 1000 * a + 63100 + 10 * b ∧
      121 ∣ ∑ i ∈ Finset.range 6, (700000 + 1000 * (a + i) + 63100 + 10 * (b + i))} 796317 := by

soln_description:
## Solution

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt[3]{n^{2}+2}-5 n^{2}}{n-\sqrt{n^{4}-n+1}}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\frac{1}{n^{2}}\left(\sqrt[3]{n^{2}+2}-5 n^{2}\right)}{\frac{1}{n^{2}}\left(n-\sqrt{n^{4}-n+1}\right)}= \\
& =\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{\sqrt[3]{\frac{1}{n^{4}}+\frac{2}{n^{6}}}-5}{\frac{1}{n}-\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{n^{3}}+\frac{1}{n^{4}}}}=\frac{\sqrt[3]{0+0}-5}{0-\sqrt{1-0+0}}=\frac{-5}{-1}=5
\end{aligned}
$$

2. 665 or 666.

Because
$$
2(a-2)>a(a \geqslant 5)
$$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
3 \times 3>2 \times 4 \\
3 \times 3>2 \times 2 \times 2 \\
3 \times 3 \times 2>4 \times 4 \\
a+1>a \times 1 \text { ( } a \text { is a positive integer) }
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, under the premise that $a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}$ is constant, to maximize $a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}$, $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ cannot contain 5 or any number greater than 5 (otherwise, by (1), 2 and 2- $a$ can replace $a$). Similarly, by (4), there can be at most one 4, by (3) there can be at most two 2s, by (5) there cannot be 1, and by (2) 2 and 4 cannot coexist.

Thus, $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ can either have two 2s, one 2, or one 4, with the rest being 3s.

Since $1996=665 \times 3+1=664 \times 3+4=664 \times 3+2$ +2,
so $a=665$ or 666.
informal_statement: 2. Given positive integers $n$ and $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ such that $a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}=1996$, and the product is maximized. Then $n=$ $\qquad$

import Mathlib

/- 2. Given positive integers $n$ and $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ such that $a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}=1996$, and the product is maximized. Then $n=$ $\qquad$ -/
theorem number_theory_324775 (n : ℕ) (a : Fin n → ℕ)

soln_description:
Solution.

D: $\quad\left\{\begin{array}{l}x \neq 0, \\ 27-3^{1 / x}>0 .\end{array}\right.$
$\lg 3^{1+\frac{1}{2 x}}+\lg 2=\lg \left(27-3^{\frac{1}{x}}\right) \lg \left(2 \cdot 3^{1+\frac{1}{2 x}}\right)=\lg \left(27-3^{\frac{1}{x}}\right)$

$2 \cdot 3^{1+\frac{1}{2 x}}=27-3^{\frac{1}{x}}, 3^{\frac{1}{x}}+6 \cdot 3^{\frac{1}{2 x}}-27=0$.

This equation is quadratic in terms of $3^{\frac{1}{2 x}}$; we find $3^{\frac{1}{2 x}}=-9$, which is not valid, and $3^{\frac{1}{2 x}}=3$, from which $x=\frac{1}{2}$.

Answer: $\frac{1}{2}$.

    (1 + 1 / (2 * x)) * log 3 + log 2 = log (27 - 3 ^ (1 / x)) ↔ x = 1 / 2 := by

B1. If we divide the polynomial $100 n^{5}-n^{4}-50 n^{3}+2 n^{2}-290 n-2$ by the polynomial $n^{2}-2$, we get the result $100 n^{3}-n^{2}+150 n$ and the remainder $10 n-2$. Therefore,

$$
\frac{100 n^{5}-n^{4}-50 n^{3}+2 n^{2}-290 n-2}{n^{2}-2}=100 n^{3}-n^{2}+150 n+\frac{10 n-2}{n^{2}-2}
$$

This number will be an integer exactly when $\frac{10 n-2}{n^{2}-2}$ is an integer. We observe that for $n>10$ the numerator of this fraction is smaller than the denominator and both are positive, so $0<\frac{10 n-2}{n^{2}-2}<1$. Therefore, for $n>10$ the fraction $\frac{10 n-2}{n^{2}-2}$ is not an integer ..... 3 points

import Mathlib

$$

is an integer.

soln_description:
Explanation: Grouping diagonally from top-right to bottom-left:
(1), (2,3), (4,5,6), ,

The $k$-th group has $k$ numbers, and the column of the first number in this group is the $k$-th column. The first $k-1$ groups have
$$
1+2+3+\cdots+(k-1)=\frac{k(k-1)}{2}
$$

numbers.
Let the number in the $i$-th row and $j$-th column be $a_{ij}$, which is in the $k$-th group. Starting from $a_{ij}$, moving up one number in the direction of the arrow increases the column $j$ by 1. Moving up $i-1$ numbers gives the first number of the group, so $k=j+i-1$. $a_{ij}$ is the $i$-th number in the $j+i-1$ group, which is equal to the last number of the $j+i-2$ group plus $i$, i.e.,
$$
a_{ij}=\frac{(i+j-2)(i+j-1)}{2}+i.
$$
(1) Substituting $i=3, j=8$ into (1) gives the number in the 3rd row and 8th column as 48.
(2) Suppose 321 is in the $k$-th group, then
$$
\frac{k(k-1)}{2}+1 \leqslant 321<\frac{k(k+1)}{2}+1.
$$

Solving this gives $k=25$.
$$
\text{Hence }\left\{\begin{array}{l}
j+i-1=25, \\
a_{ij}=\frac{(i+j-2)(i+j-1)}{2}+i=321.
\end{array}\right.
$$

Solving this gives $i=21, j=5$.
Therefore, 321 is located in the 21st row and 5th column.
(3) Let the sequence satisfying the condition be $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$. $b_{n}$ is the middle number of the $2n-1$ group, and the first and last numbers of this group are
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{(2n-1)(2n-2)}{2}+1, \\
\frac{(2n-1)(2n-2)}{2}+2n-1.
\end{array}
$$

Since $b_{n}$ is the arithmetic mean of the two, we have
$$
b_{n}=2n^2-2n+1.
$$
(4) $S_{n}=2\left(1^2+2^2+\cdots+n^2\right)-2(1+2+\cdots+n)+n$
$$
=\frac{n\left(2n^2+1\right)}{3}.
$$
informal_statement:
Example 4 Figure 1 is a chessboard that can extend infinitely to the right and downward, with horizontal rows and vertical columns. Fill in the squares with positive integers according to the pattern shown in the $4 \times 4$ grid already filled.
(1) Find the number in the square located at the 3rd row and 8th column;
(2) In which square is the number 321?
(3) Write the general term formula for the sequence of numbers in the squares along the diagonal from the top-left corner to the bottom-right corner.
(4) Find the sum of the first $n$ terms, $S_{n}$, of the sequence in (3).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 4 Figure 1 is a chessboard that can extend infinitely to the right and downward, with horizontal rows and vertical columns. Fill in the squares with positive integers according to the pattern shown in the $4 \times 4$ grid already filled.
(1) Find the number in the square located at the 3rd row and 8th column;
(2) In which square is the number 321?
(3) Write the general term formula for the sequence of numbers in the squares along the diagonal from the top-left corner to the bottom-right corner.
(4) Find the sum of the first $n$ terms, $S_{n}$, of the sequence in (3). -/
theorem algebra_297773 (a : ℕ → ℕ → ℕ)
    (h₀ : ∀ n, a n 0 = n + 1)
    (h₁ : ∀ n, a n 1 = 2 * n + 1)
    (h₂ : ∀ n, a n 2 = 3 * n + 1)
    (h₃ : ∀ n, a n 3 = 4 * n + 1) :
    a 3 8 = 48 ∧
    a 21 5 = 321 ∧
    ∀ n, a n n = 2 * n ^ 2 - 2 * n + 1 ∧
    ∀ n, ∑ i in Finset.range n, a i i = n * (2 * n ^ 2 + 1) / 3 := by

soln_description:
4. $a_{n}=9^{n}$.

Since $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$ is a geometric sequence, its subsequence $\left\{b_{2 n-1}\right\}$ is also a geometric sequence.

And $b_{2 n-1}=a_{n}$, so $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ is also a geometric sequence, with the common ratio $q$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { By } b_{1}=a_{1}, b_{2}=\sqrt{a_{3}}, b_{3}=a_{2} \\
\Rightarrow a_{3}=a_{1} a_{2} \Rightarrow a_{1}=q . \\
\text { Also } a_{2}+b_{2}=108 \text {, so } \\
q^{2}+q^{\frac{3}{2}}=108 \Rightarrow q=9 \Rightarrow a_{n}=9^{n} .
\end{array}
$$

Upon verification, $a_{n}=9^{n}$ satisfies the given conditions.
informal_statement:
4. Given the sequences $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ and $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$ satisfy:
$$
b_{n}=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
a_{\frac{n+1}{2}}, & n \text { is odd; } \\
\sqrt{a_{n+1}}, & n \text { is even. }
\end{array}\right.
$$

If $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$ is a geometric sequence, and $a_{2}+b_{2}=108$, then the general term formula of the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ is . $\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 4. Given the sequences $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ and $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$ satisfy:
$$
b_{n}=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
a_{\frac{n+1}{2}}, & n \text { is odd; } \\
\sqrt{a_{n+1}}, & n \text { is even. }
\end{array}\right.
$$

If $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$ is a geometric sequence, and $a_{2}+b_{2}=108$, then the general term formula of the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ is . $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_168352 {a b : ℕ → ℝ} (ha : ∀ n, a (n + 1) > 0)
    (hb : ∀ n, Odd n → b n = a ((n + 1) / 2)) (hb' : ∀ n, Even n → b n = Real.sqrt (a (n + 1)))
    (hge : ∃ r, ∀ n, b (n + 1) = r * b n) (h2 : a 2 + b 2 = 108) :
    ∀ n, a n = 9 ^ n := by

soln_description:
Solve for all integer values of $n$: $-2, -1, 10, 19, 34, 342$.
i) For $n=-2$, $p(x)=x^{5}+2 x=x\left(x^{4}+2\right)$; for $n=-1$, $p(x)=x^{5}+x-1=\left(x^{2}-x+1\right)\left(x^{3}+x^{2}-1\right)$; for $n=10$, $p(x)=x^{5}-10 x-12=(x-2)\left(x^{4}+2 x^{3}+4 x^{2}+8 x+6\right)$; for $n=19$, $p(x)=x^{5}-19 x-21=\left(x^{2}-x-3\right)\left(x^{3}+x^{2}+4 x+7\right)$; for $n=34$, $p(x)=x^{5}-34 x-36=(x+2)\left(x^{4}-2 x^{3}+4 x^{2}-8 x-18\right)$; for $n=342$, $p(x)=x^{3}-342 x-344=(x+1)\left(x^{4}-4 x^{3}+16 x^{2}-64 x-86\right)$.
ii) Polynomial: Suppose $p(x)=x^{5}-n x-n-2$ can be factored into the product of two non-constant integer polynomials, we will show: $n \in \{-2, -1, 10, 19, 34, 342\}$.
a) If the equation $p(x)=0$ has an integer root $\alpha$, then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\alpha^{5}-n \alpha-n-2=0 \\
\Leftrightarrow \alpha^{5}-2=n(\alpha+1) \\
\Leftrightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\alpha \neq-1, \\
n=\frac{\alpha^{5}-2}{\alpha+1}.
\end{array}\right.
\end{array}
$$

Since $n \in \mathbf{Z}$, we know $(\alpha+1) \mid (\alpha-2)$. Also, $(\alpha+1) \mid (\alpha^{5}+1)$. Therefore, $(\alpha+1) \mid \left((\alpha^{5}+1)-(\alpha^{5}-2)\right)$, which means $(\alpha+1) \mid 3$. Thus, $\alpha \in \{-4, -2, 0, 2\}$, so $n \in \{-2, 10, 34, 342\}$.
b) If $p(x)=\left(x^{2}+a x+b\right)\left(x^{3}+c x^{2}+d x+e\right)$, where $a, b, c, d, e \in \mathbf{Z}$, then comparing the coefficients of corresponding terms, we get
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
a+c=0, \\
a c+b+d=0, \\
a d+b c+e=0, \\
b d+a e=-n, \\
b e=-(n+2),
\end{array}\right.
$$

From (1), we get $c=-a$. Substituting into (2) and (5), we get $d=a^{2}-b$,
Combining (3), we get $e=-a d-b c=-a\left(a^{2}-b\right)-b(-a)=2 a b-a^{3}$,
From (5), (1), and (7), we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
-n=b\left(a^{2}-b\right)+a\left(2 a b-a^{3}\right), \\
-(n+2)=b\left(2 a b-a^{3}\right),
\end{array}
$$
(8) minus (9) gives
$$
\begin{array}{l}
2=b\left(a^{2}-b\right)+a\left(2 a b-a^{3}\right)-b\left(2 a b-a^{3}\right) \\
\Leftrightarrow(2 a+1) b^{2}-\left(a^{3}+3 a^{2}\right) b+\left(a^{4}+2\right)=0 .
\end{array}
$$

Since $2 a+1 \neq 0$, we get $\Delta=\left(a^{3}+3 a^{2}\right)^{2}-4(2 a+1)\left(a^{4}+2\right)$ is a perfect square. That is, $\Delta=a^{6}-2 a^{5}+5 a^{4}-16 a-8=\left(a^{3}-a^{2}+2 a+2\right)^{2}-24 a-12$ is a perfect square.
When $a \geq 4$, it is clear that $\Delta < 0$.
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left(a^{3}-a^{2}+2 a+2\right)^{2}>\Delta>\left(a^{3}-a^{2}+2 a+1\right)^{2},
\end{array}
$$

This contradicts $\Delta$ being a perfect square!
When $a \leq -3$, similarly, we get
$$
\left(a^{3}-a^{2}+2 a+2\right)^{2}<\Delta<\left(a^{3}-a^{2}+2 a+1\right)^{2}.
$$

This contradicts $\Delta$ being a perfect square!
In summary, $-2 \leq a \leq 3$. It is easy to verify that only when $a=-1$, $\Delta$ is a perfect square. Substituting into (1), we get $-b^{2}-2 b+3=0$, solving for $b=-1$ or 3, substituting into (8), we get $n=-1$ or 19.
Combining a) and b), we know (*) holds.
Combining i) and ii), we get $n=-2, -1, 10, 19, 34, 342$.
informal_statement: 210 Test all integers $n$ such that the polynomial $p(x)=x^{5}-n x^{2}-n-2$ can be expressed as the product of two non-constant polynomials with integer coefficients.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 210 Test all integers $n$ such that the polynomial $p(x)=x^{5}-n x^{2}-n-2$ can be expressed as the product of two non-constant polynomials with integer coefficients. -/
theorem algebra_292855 (n : ℤ) :
    ∃ p q : Polynomial ℤ, p.degree > 0 ∧ q.degree > 0 ∧
      (X^5 - n*X^2 - n - 2 : Polynomial ℤ) =
        p * q ↔ n = -2 ∨ n = -1 ∨ n = 10 ∨ n = 19 ∨ n = 34 ∨ n = 342 := by
