informal_statement:
(Equation in $\mathbb{Z}^{2}$)

Show that the following equation has no solution in $\mathbb{Z}^{2}$:

$$
x^{2}+y^{2}=175
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- (Equation in $\mathbb{Z}^{2}$)

Show that the following equation has no solution in $\mathbb{Z}^{2}$:

$$
x^{2}+y^{2}=175
$$ -/
theorem number_theory_126327 (x y : ℤ) : ¬(x^2 + y^2 = 175) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_126327 (x y : ℤ) : ¬(x^2 + y^2 = 175) := by
  rintro h
  have h1 : x ≤ 13 := by nlinarith [sq_nonneg y, h]
  have h2 : x ≥ -14 := by nlinarith [sq_nonneg y, h]
  have h3 : y ≤ 13 := by nlinarith [sq_nonneg x, h]
  have h4 : y ≥ -14 := by nlinarith [sq_nonneg x, h]
  interval_cases x <;> interval_cases y
  <;> omega

soln_description:
Solución.

Por hipótesis, se tiene

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x_{0}^{2}+a_{1} x_{0}+b_{1}=0 \\
& \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \\
& x_{0}^{2}+a_{n} x_{0}+b_{n}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Sumando estas igualdades, resulta

$$
n x_{0}^{2}+\left(a_{1}+\cdots+a_{n}\right) x_{0}+\left(b_{1}+\cdots+b_{n}\right)=0
$$

es decir, $x_{0}$ es una raíz de la ecuación propuesta.

Por lo tanto, el discriminante de esta ecuación es no negativo y debe tener otra raíz a la que llamaremos $\bar{x}$. Por las fórmulas que relacionan los coeficientes y las raíces, se tiene

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x_{0}+x_{1}=-a_{1} \\
& \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \cdots \\
& x_{0}+x_{n}=-a_{n} \\
& x_{0}+\bar{x}=-\frac{a_{1}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

Multiplicando la última igualdad por $n$ y restando de las anteriores, resulta

$$
n \bar{x}-\left(x_{1}+\cdots+x_{n}\right)=0 \Leftrightarrow \bar{x}=\frac{x_{1}+\cdots+x_{n}}{n}
$$
informal_statement:
## Problema I - 2

Se suponen conocidas las raíces reales de las n ecuaciones de segundo grado que se indican en el siguiente cuadro:

| Ecuación | Raíces |
| :---: | :---: |
| $x^{2}+a_{1} x+b_{1}=0$ | $x_{0}, x_{1}$ |
| $x^{2}+a_{2} x+b_{2}=0$ | $x_{0}, x_{2}$ |
| $\cdots$ | $\cdots$ |
| $x^{2}+a_{n} x+b_{n}=0$ | $x_{0}, x_{n}$ |

Encontrar, razonadamente, las raíces de la ecuación

$$
x^{2}+\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} x+\frac{b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}}{n}=0
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Problema I - 2

Se suponen conocidas las raíces reales de las n ecuaciones de segundo grado que se indican en el siguiente cuadro:

| Ecuación | Raíces |
| :---: | :---: |
| $x^{2}+a_{1} x+b_{1}=0$ | $x_{0}, x_{1}$ |
| $x^{2}+a_{2} x+b_{2}=0$ | $x_{0}, x_{2}$ |
| $\cdots$ | $\cdots$ |
| $x^{2}+a_{n} x+b_{n}=0$ | $x_{0}, x_{n}$ |

Encontrar, razonadamente, las raíces de la ecuación

$$
x^{2}+\frac{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}{n} x+\frac{b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}}{n}=0
$$ -/
theorem algebra_176520 (n : ℕ) (a b : Fin n → ℝ) (x : Fin n → ℝ)
    (h : ∀ i, x i ^ 2 + a i * x i + b i = 0) :
    (∑ i, x i) / n ^ 2 + (∑ i, a i) / n * (∑ i, x i) / n +
    (∑ i, b i) / n = 0 := by

soln_description:
(14) Method 1: From $x+3 y+2 z=6$, we have $x+3 y=2(3-z)$, thus $x, 3-z, 3 y$ form an arithmetic sequence. Let
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=3-z+d \\
3 y=3-z-d
\end{array}\right.
$$

Then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
8 \geqslant x^{2}+9 y^{2}-2 x-6 y+4 z \\
=[(3-z)+d]^{2}+[(3-z)-d]^{2}-2(3-z+d)-2(3-z-d)+4 z \\
\quad=2(3-z)^{2}+2 d^{2}-6+2 z-2 d-6+2 z+2 d+4 z \\
\quad=2 z^{2}-12 z+18+2 d^{2}-12+8 z \\
\quad=2 z^{2}-4 z+2 d^{2}+6 \\
\quad=2(z-1)^{2}+2 d^{2}+4
\end{array}
$$

Thus, $2 \geqslant(z-1)^{2}+d^{2}$, hence
$$
\begin{array}{l}
|d| \leqslant \sqrt{2-(z-1)^{2}}, \\
\sqrt{2}-1 \leqslant z \leqslant \sqrt{2}+1 .
\end{array}
$$

Noting that
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=3-z+d, \\
y=2-\frac{2}{3} z-\frac{1}{3} x,
\end{array}\right.
$$

we have
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\sqrt{2}-1 \leqslant z \leqslant \sqrt{2}+1, \\
3-z-\sqrt{2-(z-1)^{2}} \leqslant x \leqslant 3-z+\sqrt{2-(z-1)^{2}}, \\
y=2-\frac{2}{3} z-\frac{1}{3} x,
\end{array}\right.
$$

Thus, the solution set is
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left\{(x, y, z) \left\lvert\, y=2-\frac{2}{3} z-\frac{1}{3} x\right.\right. \\
3-z-\sqrt{2-(z-1)^{2}} \leqslant x \leqslant 3-z+\sqrt{2-(z-1)^{2}}, \\
\sqrt{2}-1 \leqslant z \leqslant \sqrt{2}+1\} .
\end{array}
$$

Method 2: Substituting $2 z=6-x-3 y$ into the inequality, we get
$$
x^{2}+9 y^{2}-2 x-6 y+2(6-x-3 y) \leqslant 8,
$$

which simplifies to
$$
(x-2)^{2}+(3 y-2)^{2} \leqslant 4 .
$$

Thus, the solution set is
$$
\left\{(x, y, z) \left\lvert\, z=3-\frac{1}{2} x-\frac{3}{2} y\right.,(x-2)^{2}+(3 y-2)^{2} \leqslant 4\right\},
$$

or
$$
\begin{aligned}
\{(x, y, z) \mid z & =3-\frac{1}{2} x-\frac{3}{2} y, \frac{2}{3}-\frac{1}{3} \sqrt{4-(x-2)^{2}} \\
& \left.\leqslant y \leqslant \frac{2}{3}+\frac{1}{3} \sqrt{4-(x-2)^{2}}, 0 \leqslant x \leqslant 4\right\} .
\end{aligned}
$$
informal_statement:
(14) If real numbers $x, y, z$ satisfy $x+3 y+2 z=6$, solve the inequality
$$
x^{2}+9 y^{2}-2 x-6 y+4 z \leqslant 8 \text {. }
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- (14) If real numbers $x, y, z$ satisfy $x+3 y+2 z=6$, solve the inequality
$$
x^{2}+9 y^{2}-2 x-6 y+4 z \leqslant 8 \text {. }
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_237864 (x y z : ℝ) (h : x + 3 * y + 2 * z = 6) :
    x^2 + 9 * y^2 - 2 * x - 6 * y + 4 * z ≤ 8 ↔
    (3 - 1 / 2 * x - 3 / 2 * y = z ∧ (x - 2)^2 + (3 * y - 2)^2 ≤ 4) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_237864 (x y z : ℝ) (h : x + 3 * y + 2 * z = 6) :
    x^2 + 9 * y^2 - 2 * x - 6 * y + 4 * z ≤ 8 ↔
    (3 - 1 / 2 * x - 3 / 2 * y = z ∧ (x - 2)^2 + (3 * y - 2)^2 ≤ 4) := by
  constructor
  · -- Assume left to right
    intro h1
    have hz : z = 3 - 1 / 2 * x - 3 / 2 * y := by
      linarith
    constructor
    · -- Show that z is expressed in terms of x and y
      linarith
    · -- Show that (x - 2)^2 + (3 * y - 2)^2 ≤ 4
      rw [show z = 3 - 1 / 2 * x - 3 / 2 * y by linarith [hz]] at h1
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 2), sq_nonneg (y - 2 / 3), sq_nonneg (3 * y - 2)]
  · -- Assume right to left
    rintro ⟨hz, h2⟩
    rw [show z = 3 - 1 / 2 * x - 3 / 2 * y by linarith [hz]]
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 2), sq_nonneg (y - 2 / 3), sq_nonneg (3 * y - 2)]

soln_description: The total age of the "older" group is not less than $20 / 33 \cdot 430=260.6 \ldots$ years.
informal_statement:
In a class of 33 students, the total age of all of them is 430 years.

Prove that if you select the 20 oldest among them, their combined age will be no less than 260 years. (The age of any student is an integer.)

#
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- In a class of 33 students, the total age of all of them is 430 years.

Prove that if you select the 20 oldest among them, their combined age will be no less than 260 years. (The age of any student is an integer.)

# -/
theorem inequalities_205625 (a : Fin 33 → ℕ) (h₀ : ∑ i, a i = 430) :
    ∃ s : Finset (Fin 33), s.card = 20 ∧ ∑ i ∈ s, a i ≥ 260 := by

soln_description:
Prove that for $a=\frac{x}{y}, b=\frac{y}{z}, c=\frac{z}{x}$, where $x, y, z$ are positive real numbers, the original inequality is equivalent to
$$(x+y-z)(y+z-x)(x+z-y) \leqslant x y z .$$

Let $u=x+z-y, v=x+y-z, w=y+z-x$. Since the sum of any two of these numbers is positive, at most one of them can be non-positive. If exactly one of them is not positive, then $u v w \leqslant 0 < x y z$, and the inequality is proved.
If all three numbers are greater than zero, then by the AM-GM inequality we have
$$\sqrt{u v}=\sqrt{(x-y+z)(y-z+x)} \leqslant \frac{(x-y+z)+(y-z+x)}{2}=x,$$

Similarly, $\sqrt{v w} \leqslant y, \sqrt{w u} \leqslant z$. Thus, $u v w \leqslant x y z$, and the inequality is proved.
informal_statement: ■ Example 9 Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers, and satisfy $abc=1$. Prove: $\left(a-1+\frac{1}{b}\right)\left(b-1+\frac{1}{c}\right)\left(c-1+\frac{1}{a}\right) \leqslant 1$. (41st IMO Problem)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ■ Example 9 Let $a, b, c$ be positive real numbers, and satisfy $abc=1$. Prove: $\left(a-1+\frac{1}{b}\right)\left(b-1+\frac{1}{c}\right)\left(c-1+\frac{1}{a}\right) \leqslant 1$. (41st IMO Problem) -/
theorem inequalities_598098 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (habc : a * b * c = 1) :
    (a - 1 + 1 / b) * (b - 1 + 1 / c) * (c - 1 + 1 / a) ≤ 1 := by

informal_statement: Xiao Di wrote the positive integers from $1$ to $n$ on the blackboard, Xiao Ke erased one of them, and Xiao Bei calculated the arithmetic mean of the remaining numbers, which was $30.8$. Find the number that Xiao Ke erased.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Xiao Di wrote the positive integers from $1$ to $n$ on the blackboard, Xiao Ke erased one of them, and Xiao Bei calculated the arithmetic mean of the remaining numbers, which was $30.8$. Find the number that Xiao Ke erased. -/
theorem number_theory_3876 (n : ℕ) (h : n > 0) (a : Finset ℕ) (ha : a ⊆ Finset.Icc 1 n)
    (h' : (a \ {x}).card = n - 1) (h'' : ∑ y ∈ (a \ {x}), y = 30 * (n - 1) + 8) :
    x = 43 := by

soln_description:
Solution

Let $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots, a_{n}$ be Alice's numbers. Below, when $X$ is a finite set of integers, we will denote $\prod X$ as the product of its elements. Furthermore, we denote $\mathcal{P}_{i}$ as the set of prime factors of $a_{i}$, and $\mathcal{P}$ as the union of all sets $\mathcal{P}_{i}$, that is, the set of all prime numbers dividing at least one number $a_{i}$.

When Alice erases two numbers $a_{i}$ and $a_{j}$ and replaces them with the numbers $q=\prod\left(\mathcal{P}_{i} \cup \mathcal{P}_{j}\right)$ and $q^{2}$, she does not modify the set $\mathcal{P}$, and replaces each of the sets $\mathcal{P}_{i}$ and $\mathcal{P}_{j}$ with their union $\mathcal{P}_{i} \cup \mathcal{P}_{j}$. Thus, for all $i$, the set $\mathcal{P}_{i}$ can only grow (in terms of inclusion) during the process, and since it is constrained to remain a subset of $\mathcal{P}$, there is a point in time after which $\mathcal{P}_{i}$ will no longer change.

By selecting the latest of these moments as $i$ varies, we obtain a moment, say $m$, from which no set $\mathcal{P}_{i}$ will change. We can even choose this moment so that any number $a_{i}$ on which Alice acts at some point has already been erased and replaced.

Finally, we say that a number $a_{i}$ is small if it is equal to the product $\prod\left(\mathcal{P}_{i}\right)$, and large if it is equal to $\prod\left(\mathcal{P}_{i}\right)^{2}$; otherwise, it is neutral. Each time a number $a_{i}$ undergoes an operation, it becomes small or large; subsequently, it will always be either small or large.

But then, from the moment $m$ onward, the list of numbers on the board will never change again. Indeed, if Alice erases two integers $a_{i}$ and $a_{j}$, each of the integers $a_{i}$ and $a_{j}$ was already small or large. Since $\mathcal{P}_{i}=\mathcal{P}_{i} \cup \mathcal{P}_{j}=\mathcal{P}_{j}$ and $a_{i} \neq a_{j}$, it follows that one of the integers $a_{i}$ and $a_{j}$ is small, and the other is large. But then the numbers $q$ and $q^{2}$ that Alice writes are equal to the integers $a_{i}$ and $a_{j}$ that she just erased.

## $\square$
informal_statement:
Problem 2

On her board, Alice has written $n$ integers greater than or equal to two, not necessarily distinct. She then has the right, as many times as she wishes, to erase two distinct numbers $a$ and $b$ and replace them with $q$ and $q^{2}$, where $q$ denotes the product of all the prime factors of $a b$ (each prime factor is counted only once). For example, if Alice erases the numbers 4 and 6, the prime factors of $a b=2^{3} \times 3$ are 2 and 3, so Alice writes $q=6$ and $q^{2}=36$.

Prove that, after a certain time, and regardless of Alice's strategy, the list of numbers written on the board will no longer change.

Note: The order of the numbers in the list is considered irrelevant.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Problem 2

On her board, Alice has written $n$ integers greater than or equal to two, not necessarily distinct. She then has the right, as many times as she wishes, to erase two distinct numbers $a$ and $b$ and replace them with $q$ and $q^{2}$, where $q$ denotes the product of all the prime factors of $a b$ (each prime factor is counted only once). For example, if Alice erases the numbers 4 and 6, the prime factors of $a b=2^{3} \times 3$ are 2 and 3, so Alice writes $q=6$ and $q^{2}=36$.

Prove that, after a certain time, and regardless of Alice's strategy, the list of numbers written on the board will no longer change.

Note: The order of the numbers in the list is considered irrelevant. -/
theorem number_theory_295682 (S : Finset ℕ) (hS : ∀ n ∈ S, n ≥ 2) :
    ∃ T : Finset ℕ, T ⊆ S ∧ ∀ m ∈ T, ∀ n ∈ T, m ≠ n → ¬(∃ q : ℕ, q > 0 ∧ q^2 = m * n) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_295682 (S : Finset ℕ) (hS : ∀ n ∈ S, n ≥ 2) :
    ∃ T : Finset ℕ, T ⊆ S ∧ ∀ m ∈ T, ∀ n ∈ T, m ≠ n → ¬(∃ q : ℕ, q > 0 ∧ q^2 = m * n) := by
  use ∅
  constructor
  · -- Show that ∅ ⊆ S
    simp
  · -- Show that all numbers in T are greater than 2
    simp
    all_goals tauto
    all_goals simp [Finset.mem_empty]
    all_goals tauto
    all_goals simp [Finset.mem_empty]
    all_goals tauto

informal_statement: Let the function $f$: ${1,2,3} \to {2,3,4}$ satisfy $f[f(x)-1]=f(x)$, then the number of such functions is ___          ___ .
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let the function $f$: ${1,2,3} \to {2,3,4}$ satisfy $f[f(x)-1]=f(x)$, then the number of such functions is ___          ___. -/
/- Let the function $f$: ${1,2,3} \to {2,3,4}$ satisfy $f[f(x)-1]=f(x)$, then the number of such functions is ___          ___ . -/
theorem algebra_8398 :
    Set.ncard {f : Fin 3 → Fin 3 | ∀ x, f (f x - 1) = f x} = 10 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- Let the function $f$: ${1,2,3} \to {2,3,4}$ satisfy $f[f(x)-1]=f(x)$, then the number of such functions is ___          ___. -/
theorem algebra_8398 :
    Set.ncard {f : Fin 3 → Fin 3 | ∀ x, f (f x - 1) = f x} = 10 := by
  rw [Set.ncard_eq_toFinset_card']
  simp [Finset.card]
  <;> native_decide

informal_statement: 4. [30] Let $a$ and $b$ be real numbers greater than 1 such that $a b=100$. The maximum possible value of $a^{\left(\log _{10} b\right)^{2}}$ can be written in the form $10^{x}$ for some real number $x$. Find $x$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 4. [30] Let $a$ and $b$ be real numbers greater than 1 such that $a b=100$. The maximum possible value of $a^{\left(\log _{10} b\right)^{2}}$ can be written in the form $10^{x}$ for some real number $x$. Find $x$. -/
theorem algebra_171272 (a b : ℝ) (ha : 1 < a) (hb : 1 < b)
    (hab : a * b = 100) :
    IsGreatest {x | ∃ a b : ℝ, 1 < a ∧ 1 < b ∧ a * b = 100 ∧ x = a ^ ((logb 10 b) ^ 2)} (32 / 27) := by

soln_description:
【Analysis】Let's assume the common difference of the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ is $d$. Clearly, when $d=0$, the equality in (1) holds.
Hereafter, let's assume $d \neq 0$.
Notice that, on the right side of inequality (1),
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{a_{1} a_{n}+a_{2} a_{n+1}}{a_{1} a_{2} a_{n} a_{n+1}}=\frac{1}{a_{2} a_{n+1}}+\frac{1}{a_{1} a_{n}} \\
=\frac{1}{(n-1) d}\left(\frac{1}{a_{2}}-\frac{1}{a_{n+1}}+\frac{1}{a_{1}}-\frac{1}{a_{n}}\right) .
\end{array}
$$

Thus, the original proposition
$$
\Leftrightarrow \frac{1}{a_{2}^{2}}+\frac{1}{a_{3}^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}^{2}} \leqslant \frac{1}{2 d}\left(\frac{1}{a_{2}}-\frac{1}{a_{n+1}}+\frac{1}{a_{1}}-\frac{1}{a_{n}}\right) \text {. }
$$

When $k \geqslant 2$, we have
$$
\begin{aligned}
a_{k}^{2} & >a_{k}^{2}-d^{2}=\left(a_{k}+d\right)\left(a_{k}-d\right)=a_{k+1} a_{k-1} \\
\Rightarrow & \frac{1}{a_{k}^{2}}<\frac{1}{a_{k-1} a_{k+1}}=\frac{1}{2 d} \cdot \frac{a_{k+1}-a_{k-1}}{a_{k-1} a_{k+1}} \\
& =\frac{1}{2 d}\left(\frac{1}{a_{k-1}}-\frac{1}{a_{k+1}}\right) \\
\Rightarrow & \sum_{k=2}^{n} \frac{1}{a_{k}^{2}}<\frac{1}{2 d} \sum_{k=2}^{n}\left(\frac{1}{a_{k-1}}-\frac{1}{a_{k+1}}\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{2 d}\left(\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}-\frac{1}{a_{n}}-\frac{1}{a_{n+1}}\right) \\
& =\frac{n-1}{2} \cdot \frac{a_{1} a_{n}+a_{2} a_{n+1}}{a_{1} a_{2} a_{n} a_{n+1}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, the equality in the original inequality holds $\Leftrightarrow d=0$.
【Note】This is an inequality about an arithmetic sequence. Starting from the equivalent transformation of the right side of the inequality, and using
$$
a_{k}^{2} \geqslant a_{k}^{2}-d^{2}=\left(a_{k}+d\right)\left(a_{k}-d\right)=a_{k+1} a_{k-1}
$$

the proof is completed.
informal_statement:
Example 2 Let $n \geqslant 2, a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n+1}$ be positive numbers, and
$$
a_{2}-a_{1}=a_{3}-a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n+1}-a_{n} \geqslant 0 \text {. }
$$

Prove:
$$
\frac{1}{a_{2}^{2}}+\frac{1}{a_{3}^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}^{2}} \leqslant \frac{n-1}{2} \cdot \frac{a_{1} a_{n}+a_{2} a_{n+1}}{a_{1} a_{2} a_{n} a_{n+1}},
$$

and determine the condition for equality. ${ }^{[1]}$
(7th Hong Kong Mathematical Olympiad)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Example 2 Let $n \geqslant 2, a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n+1}$ be positive numbers, and
$$
a_{2}-a_{1}=a_{3}-a_{2}=\cdots=a_{n+1}-a_{n} \geqslant 0 \text {. }
$$

Prove:
$$
\frac{1}{a_{2}^{2}}+\frac{1}{a_{3}^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{n}^{2}} \leqslant \frac{n-1}{2} \cdot \frac{a_{1} a_{n}+a_{2} a_{n+1}}{a_{1} a_{2} a_{n} a_{n+1}},
$$

and determine the condition for equality. ${ }^{[1]}$
(7th Hong Kong Mathematical Olympiad) -/
theorem inequalities_325460 {n : ℕ} (hn : 2 ≤ n) (a : ℕ → ℝ)
    (ha : ∀ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 (n + 1), 0 < a i) (h : ∃ x, ∀ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, a (i + 1) - a i = x)
    (hx : 0 ≤ x) :
    ∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 2 n, (1 / (a i)^2) ≤ ((n - 1) / 2) * ((a 1) * (a n) + (a 2) * (a (n + 1))) / ((a 1) * (a 2) * (a n) * (a (n + 1))) ∧
    (∑ i ∈ Finset.Icc 2 n, (1 / (a i)^2) = ((n - 1) / 2) * ((a 1) * (a n) + (a 2) * (a (n + 1))) / ((a 1) * (a 2) * (a n) * (a (n + 1))) ↔
      (∀ i ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, a (i + 1) = a i)) := by

soln_description:
Replace the $x$ in $F$ with $\frac{3x+x^3}{1+3x^2}$.
\[\log\dfrac{1 + \frac{3x+x^3}{1+3x^2} }{1 - \frac{3x+x^3}{1+3x^2} }\]
\[\log\dfrac{\frac{1+3x^2}{1+3x^2} + \frac{3x+x^3}{1+3x^2} }{\frac{1+3x^2}{1+3x^2} - \frac{3x+x^3}{1+3x^2} }\]
\[\log (\frac{1+3x+3x^2+x^3}{1+3x^2} \div \frac{1-3x+3x^2-x^3}{1+3x^2})\]
Recall that from the [Binomial Theorem](https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/Binomial_Theorem), $(1+x)^3 = 1+3x+3x^2+x^3$ and $(1-x)^3 = 1-3x+3x^2-x^3$.
\[\log (\frac{(1+x)^3}{1+3x^2} \div \frac{(1-x)^3}{1+3x^2})\]
\[\log\dfrac{(1+x)^3}{(1-x)^3}\]
\[3 \log\dfrac{1+x}{1-x}\]
Thus, the expression is equivalent to $3F$, which is answer choice $\boxed{\textbf{(C)}}$.
informal_statement:
Let $F=\log\dfrac{1+x}{1-x}$. Find a new function $G$ by replacing each $x$ in $F$ by $\dfrac{3x+x^3}{1+3x^2}$, and simplify. 
The simplified expression $G$ is equal to:
$\textbf{(A)}\ -F \qquad \textbf{(B)}\ F\qquad \textbf{(C)}\ 3F \qquad \textbf{(D)}\ F^3 \qquad \textbf{(E)}\ F^3-F$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Let $F=\log\dfrac{1+x}{1-x}$. Find a new function $G$ by replacing each $x$ in $F$ by $\dfrac{3x+x^3}{1+3x^2}$, and simplify. 
The simplified expression $G$ is equal to:
$\textbf{(A)}\ -F \qquad \textbf{(B)}\ F\qquad \textbf{(C)}\ 3F \qquad \textbf{(D)}\ F^3 \qquad \textbf{(E)}\ F^3-F$ -/
theorem algebra_93686 {F G : ℝ → ℝ}
    (hF : F = fun x => log ((1 + x) / (1 - x))) :
    G = fun x => 3 * F ((3 * x + x ^ 3) / (1 + 3 * x ^ 2)) := by

soln_description:
1. Given the conditions:
   \[
   abc = 1
   \]
   and
   \[
   a^2 + b^2 + c^2 - \left( \frac{1}{a^2} + \frac{1}{b^2} + \frac{1}{c^2} \right) = 8(a + b + c) - 8(ab + bc + ca)
   \]

2. Let \( \sum a = p \) and \( \sum ab = q \). The second condition can be rewritten using these notations:
   \[
   a^2 + b^2 + c^2 - \left( \frac{1}{a^2} + \frac{1}{b^2} + \frac{1}{c^2} \right) = 8p - 8q
   \]

3. Using the identity \( a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = p^2 - 2q \) and the fact that \( \frac{1}{a^2} + \frac{1}{b^2} + \frac{1}{c^2} = \frac{b^2c^2 + c^2a^2 + a^2b^2}{a^2b^2c^2} = \frac{q^2 - 2p}{1} \) (since \( abc = 1 \)), we can rewrite the equation as:
   \[
   (p^2 - 2q) - (q^2 - 2p) = 8p - 8q
   \]

4. Simplifying the equation:
   \[
   p^2 - 2q - q^2 + 2p = 8p - 8q
   \]
   \[
   p^2 - q^2 + 2p - 2q = 8p - 8q
   \]
   \[
   p^2 - q^2 + 2p - 2q = 8p - 8q
   \]
   \[
   p^2 - q^2 + 2p - 2q = 8p - 8q
   \]
   \[
   p^2 - q^2 = 6p - 6q
   \]
   \[
   (p - q)(p + q) = 6(p - q)
   \]

5. Since \( p \neq q \) (otherwise the expression \( \frac{1}{a-1} + \frac{1}{b-1} + \frac{1}{c-1} \) would be undefined), we can divide both sides by \( p - q \):
   \[
   p + q = 6
   \]

6. Now, we need to find the value of the expression \( \frac{1}{a-1} + \frac{1}{b-1} + \frac{1}{c-1} \). Using the identity for symmetric sums, we have:
   \[
   \sum_{sym} \frac{1}{a-1} = \frac{3 - 2p + q}{p - q}
   \]

7. Substituting \( p + q = 6 \) into the expression:
   \[
   \sum_{sym} \frac{1}{a-1} = \frac{3 - 2p + q}{p - q}
   \]

8. Since \( p + q = 6 \), we can express \( q \) as \( 6 - p \):
   \[
   \sum_{sym} \frac{1}{a-1} = \frac{3 - 2p + (6 - p)}{p - (6 - p)}
   \]
   \[
   \sum_{sym} \frac{1}{a-1} = \frac{3 - 2p + 6 - p}{p - 6 + p}
   \]
   \[
   \sum_{sym} \frac{1}{a-1} = \frac{9 - 3p}{2p - 6}
   \]
   \[
   \sum_{sym} \frac{1}{a-1} = \frac{9 - 3p}{2(p - 3)}
   \]
   \[
   \sum_{sym} \frac{1}{a-1} = \frac{3(3 - p)}{2(p - 3)}
   \]
   \[
   \sum_{sym} \frac{1}{a-1} = -\frac{3}{2}
   \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{-\frac{3}{2}}\).
informal_statement:
Real numbers $a$, $b$, $c$ which are differ from $1$ satisfies the following conditions;
(1) $abc =1$
(2) $a^2+b^2+c^2 - \left( \dfrac{1}{a^2} + \dfrac{1}{b^2} + \dfrac{1}{c^2} \right) = 8(a+b+c) - 8 (ab+bc+ca)$
Find all possible values of expression $\dfrac{1}{a-1} + \dfrac{1}{b-1} + \dfrac{1}{c-1}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Real numbers $a$, $b$, $c$ which are differ from $1$ satisfies the following conditions;
(1) $abc =1$
(2) $a^2+b^2+c^2 - \left( \dfrac{1}{a^2} + \dfrac{1}{b^2} + \dfrac{1}{c^2} \right) = 8(a+b+c) - 8 (ab+bc+ca)$
Find all possible values of expression $\dfrac{1}{a-1} + \dfrac{1}{b-1} + \dfrac{1}{c-1}$. -/
theorem algebra_33459 {a b c : ℝ} (ha : |a - 1| > 0) (hb : |b - 1| > 0) (hc : |c - 1| > 0)
    (h1 : a * b * c = 1) (h2 : a ^ 2 + b ^ 2 + c ^ 2 - (1 / a ^ 2 + 1 / b ^ 2 + 1 / c ^ 2) =
    8 * (a + b + c) - 8 * (a * b + b * c + c * a)) :
    1 / (a - 1) + 1 / (b - 1) + 1 / (c - 1) = -3 / 2 := by

informal_statement: 2. Solve the inequality $\frac{x^{2}-2 x-15}{x-2}<0$ ,
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 2. Solve the inequality $\frac{x^{2}-2 x-15}{x-2}<0$ , -/
theorem inequalities_302246 (x : ℝ) (hx : x ≠ 2) :
    (x^2 - 2 * x - 15) / (x - 2) < 0 ↔ x ∈ Ioo 2 5 ∪ Iio (-3) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

theorem inequalities_302246 (x : ℝ) (hx : x ≠ 2) :
    (x^2 - 2 * x - 15) / (x - 2) < 0 ↔ x ∈ Ioo 2 5 ∪ Iio (-3) := by
  have h1 : x^2 - 2*x - 15 = (x - 5) * (x + 3) := by
    ring
  have h1' : (x^2 - 2*x - 15) / (x - 2) = (x - 5) * (x + 3) / (x - 2) := by
    rw [h1]
  rw [h1']
  constructor
  · -- Forward direction: if (x - 5) * (x + 3) / (x - 2) < 0 then x ∈ (2, 5) ∪ (-∞, -3)
    intro h
    have h2 : (x - 5) * (x + 3) / (x - 2) < 0 := by linarith
    have h3 : x - 2 ≠ 0 := by
      intro h4
      apply hx
      linarith
    apply div_neg_iff.mp at h2
    cases h2 with
    | inl h4 =>
      -- Case where (x - 5) * (x + 3) > 0 and x - 2 < 0, so x < 2 and (x > 5 or x < -3), which gives x < -3
      have h5 : (x - 5) * (x + 3) > 0 := by linarith
      have h6 : x - 2 < 0 := by linarith
      have h7 : x < 2 := by linarith
      have h8 : x < -3 := by nlinarith
      -- Therefore x ∈ (-∞, -3)
      right
      exact h8
    | inr h4 =>
      -- Case where (x - 5) * (x + 3) < 0 and x - 2 > 0, so x > 2 and (-3 < x < 5), which gives 2 < x < 5
      have h5 : (x - 5) * (x + 3) < 0 := by linarith
      have h6 : x - 2 > 0 := by linarith
      have h7 : x > 2 := by linarith
      have h8 : -3 < x ∧ x < 5 := by
        constructor
        · nlinarith
        · nlinarith
      -- Therefore x ∈ (2, 5)
      left
      constructor
      · linarith
      · linarith
  · -- Backward direction: if x ∈ (2, 5) ∪ (-∞, -3) then (x - 5) * (x + 3) / (x - 2) < 0
    rintro (h | h)
    · -- Case where x ∈ (2, 5)
      have h1 : 2 < x := h.1
      have h2 : x < 5 := h.2
      have h3 : x - 2 > 0 := by linarith
      have h4 : x + 3 > 0 := by nlinarith
      have h5 : x - 5 < 0 := by linarith
      have h6 : (x - 5) * (x + 3) < 0 := by nlinarith
      apply div_neg_of_neg_of_pos
      · linarith
      · linarith
    · -- Case where x ∈ (-∞, -3)
      have h1 : x < -3 := h
      have h3 : x - 2 < 0 := by linarith
      have h4 : x + 3 < 0 := by linarith
      have h5 : x - 5 < 0 := by linarith
      have h6 : (x - 5) * (x + 3) > 0 := by nlinarith
      apply div_neg_of_pos_of_neg
      · linarith
      · linarith

soln_description:
## Solution

$y^{\prime}=\left(\sqrt[3]{\cos \sqrt{2}}-\frac{1}{52} \cdot \frac{\cos ^{2} 26 x}{\sin 52 x}\right)^{\prime}=0-\frac{1}{52}\left(\frac{\cos ^{2} 26 x}{\sin 52 x}\right)^{\prime}=$

$=-\frac{1}{52} \cdot \frac{\left(\cos ^{2} 26 x\right)^{\prime} \cdot \sin 52 x-\cos ^{2} 26 x \cdot(\sin 52 x)^{\prime}}{\sin ^{2} 52 x}=$

$=-\frac{1}{52} \cdot \frac{2 \cos 26 x \cdot(-\sin 26 x) \cdot 26 \cdot \sin 52 x-\cos ^{2} 26 x \cdot \cos 52 x \cdot 52}{\sin ^{2} 52 x}=$

$=\frac{\cos 26 x \cdot \sin 26 x \cdot \sin 52 x+\cos ^{2} 26 x \cdot \cos 52 x}{\sin ^{2} 52 x}=$

$=\frac{2 \cos ^{2} 26 x \cdot \sin ^{2} 26 x+\cos ^{2} 26 x \cdot\left(1-2 \sin ^{2} 26 x\right)}{\sin ^{2} 52 x}=$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =\frac{\cos ^{2} 26 x \cdot\left(2 \sin ^{2} 26 x+1-2 \sin ^{2} 26 x\right)}{\sin ^{2} 52 x}=\frac{\cos ^{2} 26 x}{2 \sin ^{2} 26 x \cos ^{2} 26 x}= \\
& =\frac{1}{2 \sin ^{2} 26 x}
\end{aligned}
$$

## Problem Kuznetsov Differentiation 9-26
informal_statement:
## Condition of the problem

Find the derivative.

$$
y=\sqrt[3]{\cos \sqrt{2}}-\frac{1}{52} \cdot \frac{\cos ^{2} 26 x}{\sin 52 x}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- ## Condition of the problem

Find the derivative.

$$
y=\sqrt[3]{\cos \sqrt{2}}-\frac{1}{52} \cdot \frac{\cos ^{2} 26 x}{\sin 52 x}
$$ -/
theorem calculus_158121 (f : ℝ → ℝ)
  (h₀ : ∀ x, f x = (cos (sqrt 2)) ^ ((1 : ℝ) / 3) -
    (1 / 52) * (cos (26 * x)) ^ 2 / (sin (52 * x))) :
  deriv f = λ x => 1 / (2 * (sin (26 * x)) ^ 2) := by

soln_description:
a) $\left(\log _{25} 75, \log _{65} 260\right) \rightarrow\left(\log _{25} 3, \log _{65} 4\right) \rightarrow\left(\log _{4} 65, \log _{3} 25\right) \rightarrow\left(\log _{4} 65 / 4, \log _{3} 265 / 3\right) \rightarrow\left(\log _{4} 65 / 16, \log _{3} 25 / 9\right) \rightarrow$ $\left(\log _{4} 65 / 64, \log _{3} 25 / 27\right)$. Therefore, $\log _{25} 75>\log _{65} 260$.

b) Let's rephrase the problem: A device for comparing numbers $x>0$ and $y>0$ operates according to the following rules:

1) if $x>1$ and $y>1$, it transitions to comparing the numbers $x-1$ and $y-1$;
2) if $x < 1$ and $y < 1$, it transitions to comparing the numbers $x+1$ and $y+1$;
3) if $x > 1$ and $y < 1$, it transitions to comparing the numbers $x-1$ and $y+1$;
4) if $x < 1$ and $y > 1$, it transitions to comparing the numbers $x+1$ and $y-1$.

Problem 98070 Topics: [ Decomposition into products of transpositions and cycles] Difficulty: $4+$ Classes: $9,10,11$

Author: Voronin S.M.

A deck of $n$ different cards is arranged. It is allowed to move any number of adjacent cards (without changing their order and without flipping them) to another place in the deck. It is required to reverse the order of all $n$ cards using several such operations.

a) Prove that for $n=9$ this can be done in 5 operations;

Prove that for $n=52$ this

b) can be done in 27 operations

c) cannot be done in 17 operations;

d) cannot be done in 26 operations.

## Solution

a) Let's denote the cards by numbers. Suppose they are initially ordered in descending order: $9,8,7,6,5,4,3,2,1$. We will show the results of the moves, highlighting the moved cards with underscores:

| 5, | 4, | 3, | 2, | 9, | 8, | 7, | 6, | $1 ;$ |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| 5, | 4, | 3, | 8, | 7, | 6, | 1, | 2, | $9 ;$ |
| 5, | 4, | 7, | 6, | 1, | 2, | 3, | 8, | $9 ;$ |
| 5, | 6, | 1, | 2, | 3, | 4, | 7, | 8, | $9 ;$ |
| 1, | 2, | 3, | 4, | 5, | 6, | 7, | 8, | 9. |

b) Let's denote the cards by numbers from 1 to 52, assuming they are initially ordered in descending order. We will swap the halves of the deck, resulting in: $26,25, \ldots, 2,1,52,51, \ldots, 27$. Now we will move the highlighted pair of cards to the end: $26,25, \ldots, 2,51,50, \ldots, 27,1,52$. We will then insert the next pair of cards at the boundary of the two initial halves into the already moved cards: $26,25, \ldots, 3,50,49, \ldots, 27,1,2,51,52$, and continue this process. The last pair to be moved will be 26, 27, after which the deck will be ordered in ascending order. A total of $1+26=27$ operations were required.

c) We still assume that the cards are initially ordered in descending order. We call a pair of adjacent cards a disorder if the number of the left card is greater than the number of the right card. Initially, there are 51 disorders. When we remove a part of the deck, we can eliminate no more than two disorders (we break two adjacent pairs), and when we insert it into the deck, only one pair is broken, so we can eliminate no more than one disorder. This shows that fewer than 17 operations are not enough. However, 17 operations are also insufficient, since on the first step, when removing a part, the number of disorders decreases by no more than 1: if we remove a part located at the edge, then only one pair is broken, and if we remove from the middle, then one new disorder arises in the newly formed pair of adjacent cards.

d) We will prove that with each operation, the number of disorders decreases by no more than 2, and on the first and last operations - by 1. Then 26 operations are enough to eliminate $1+24 \cdot 2+1=50$ disorders, while initially there are 51.

Suppose that during a certain operation, the number of disorders decreases by 3. This means that during the removal, two disorders disappeared and no new ones arose, and during the insertion, one disappeared and no new ones arose. Let the part being removed start with card $a$ and end with card $b$ and be inserted between cards $e$ and $f$:

$$
\begin{array}{lllllllllll}
\ldots, & c, & a, & \ldots, & b, & d, & \ldots, & e, & f, & \ldots \\
\ldots, & c, & d, & \ldots, & e, & a, & \ldots, & b, & f, & \ldots
\end{array}
$$

The formulated conditions mean that $ca, b>d$, therefore, $b>a$. On the other hand, $e>f$, $eb$. The resulting contradiction proves the impossibility of eliminating three disorders in one operation.
If we insert at the edge, the number of disorders does not decrease, and if we insert inside, one disorder is eliminated, but another arises.

Similarly, the last step is considered.
informal_statement:
The device for comparing numbers $\log _{a} b$ and $\log _{c} d(a, b, c, d>1)$ operates according to the following rules: if $b>a$ and $d>c$, it transitions to comparing the numbers $\log _{a}^{b} / a$ and $\log _{c}^{d}$. If $b<a$ and $d<c$, it transitions to comparing the numbers $\log _{d} c$ and $\log _{b} a$. If $(b-a)(d-c) \leq 0$, it provides the answer.

a) Show how the device will compare the numbers $\log _{25} 75$ and $\log _{65} 260$.

b) Prove that it will compare any two unequal logarithms in a finite number of steps.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- The device for comparing numbers $\log _{a} b$ and $\log _{c} d(a, b, c, d>1)$ operates according to the following rules: if $b>a$ and $d>c$, it transitions to comparing the numbers $\log _{a}^{b} / a$ and $\log _{c}^{d}$. If $b<a$ and $d<c$, it transitions to comparing the numbers $\log _{d} c$ and $\log _{b} a$. If $(b-a)(d-c) \leq 0$, it provides the answer.

a) Show how the device will compare the numbers $\log _{25} 75$ and $\log _{65} 260$.

b) Prove that it will compare any two unequal logarithms in a finite number of steps. -/
theorem algebra_232071 {a b c d : ℝ} (ha : a > 1) (hb : b > 1) (hc : c > 1) (hd : d > 1)
    (h : b > a ∧ d > c) :
    logb 25 75 ^ (1 / 25 : ℝ) / 25 > logb 65 260 ^ (1 / 65 : ℝ) := by

soln_description:
Solution. We introduce the substitution $z=\operatorname{GCD}(x, y)$ and obtain the equation

$$
x+y^{2}+z^{2}=x y z
$$

Let $a$ and $b$ be natural numbers such that

$$
x=a z \text { and } y=b z, \operatorname{GCD}(a, b)=1
$$

Then the equation takes the form

$$
a z+b^{2} z^{2}+z^{2}=a b z^{3}
$$

or

$$
a+b^{2} z+z=a b z^{2}
$$

Since the right side of the last equation is divisible by $z$ and two of the terms on the left side are divisible by $z$, it follows that $z \mid a$. Therefore, there exists a natural number such that $a=c z$. Substituting in the last equation, we get the equation $c z+b^{2} z+z=c b z^{3}$, i.e., the equation $c+b^{2}+1=c b z^{2}$, which is equivalent to the equation

$$
b^{2}+1=c\left(b z^{2}-1\right)
$$

Clearly, $b z^{2} \neq 1$, because otherwise we get $b^{2}+1=0$, which is impossible. Thus, $c=\frac{b^{2}+1}{b z^{2}-1}$ and if we multiply the last equation by $z^{2}$, we get

$$
c z^{2}=\frac{b^{2} z^{2}+z^{2}}{b z^{2}-1}=b+\frac{b+z^{2}}{b z^{2}-1}
$$

Since $c z^{2}$ is a natural number and $\frac{b+z^{2}}{b z^{2}-1}$ is a natural number. Therefore, $b z^{2}-1 \leq b+z^{2}$, i.e.,

$$
\left(z^{2}-1\right)(b-1) \leq 2
$$

If $b=1$, then $c=\frac{2}{z^{2}-1}$, from which it follows that $z^{2}=2$ or $z^{2}=3$, which is impossible. If $b=2$, then $c=\frac{5}{2 z^{2}-1}$. If $2 z^{2}-1=1$, then $z=1$. It follows that $c=5, a=5$, i.e., $x=5$ and $y=2$. If $2 z^{2}-1=5$, then $z^{2}=3$, which is impossible. If $b=3$, then $c=\frac{10}{3 z^{2}-1}$. The cases

$$
3 z^{2}-1=1,3 z^{2}-1=5 \text { and } 3 z^{2}-1=10
$$

are not possible. If $3 z^{2}-1=2$, then $z=1$. It follows that $c=5, a=5$, i.e., $x=5$ and $y=3$. If $b>3$, then from (1) it follows that $z=1$. In the cases

$$
c=\frac{b^{2}+1}{b-1}=b+1+\frac{2}{b-1}
$$

we get $b=2$ or $b=3$, which contradicts $b>3$.

Finally, the solutions to the given equation are $(x, y)=\{(5,2),(5,3)\}$.
informal_statement:
5. In the set of natural numbers, solve the equation

$$
x+y^{2}+(\operatorname{GCD}(x, y))^{2}=x y \cdot \operatorname{GCD}(x, y)
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. In the set of natural numbers, solve the equation

$$
x+y^{2}+(\operatorname{GCD}(x, y))^{2}=x y \cdot \operatorname{GCD}(x, y)
$$ -/
theorem number_theory_233994 (x y : ℕ) :
    x + y^2 + (Nat.gcd x y)^2 = x * y * Nat.gcd x y ↔ (x, y) = (5, 2) ∨ (x, y) = (5, 3) := by

soln_description:
To find the number of squares in the sequence given by \( a_0 = 91 \) and \( a_{n+1} = 10a_n + (-1)^n \) for \( n \ge 0 \), we will analyze the sequence modulo 8 and modulo 1000.

1. **Base Cases:**
   - \( a_0 = 91 \)
   - \( a_1 = 10a_0 + (-1)^0 = 10 \cdot 91 + 1 = 911 \)
   - \( a_2 = 10a_1 + (-1)^1 = 10 \cdot 911 - 1 = 9109 \)

2. **Induction Hypothesis:**
   We will prove by induction that for \( k \ge 2 \):
   - \( a_{2k} \equiv 909 \pmod{1000} \)
   - \( a_{2k-1} \equiv 091 \pmod{1000} \)

3. **Induction Step:**
   - Assume \( a_{2k} \equiv 909 \pmod{1000} \) and \( a_{2k-1} \equiv 091 \pmod{1000} \).
   - For \( a_{2k+1} \):
     \[
     a_{2k+1} = 10a_{2k} + 1 \equiv 10 \cdot 909 + 1 \equiv 9090 + 1 \equiv 9091 \pmod{1000} \equiv 091 \pmod{1000}
     \]
   - For \( a_{2k+2} \):
     \[
     a_{2k+2} = 10a_{2k+1} - 1 \equiv 10 \cdot 091 - 1 \equiv 910 - 1 \equiv 909 \pmod{1000}
     \]

4. **Quadratic Residue Analysis:**
   - For \( a_{2k} \equiv 909 \pmod{1000} \):
     \[
     909 \equiv 5 \pmod{8}
     \]
     Since 5 is not a quadratic residue modulo 8, \( a_{2k} \) cannot be a perfect square.
   - For \( a_{2k-1} \equiv 091 \pmod{1000} \):
     \[
     091 \equiv 3 \pmod{8}
     \]
     Since 3 is not a quadratic residue modulo 8, \( a_{2k-1} \) cannot be a perfect square.

5. **Conclusion:**
   - For \( n \ge 3 \), \( a_n \) is not a square.
   - Checking the initial terms:
     - \( a_0 = 91 \) is not a perfect square.
     - \( a_1 = 911 \) is not a perfect square.
     - \( a_2 = 9109 \) is not a perfect square.

Thus, there are no perfect squares in the sequence.

The final answer is \(\boxed{0}\).
informal_statement: Find the number of squares in the sequence given by $ a_0\equal{}91$ and $ a_{n\plus{}1}\equal{}10a_n\plus{}(\minus{}1)^n$ for $ n \ge 0.$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find the number of squares in the sequence given by $ a_0\equal{}91$ and $ a_{n\plus{}1}\equal{}10a_n\plus{}(\minus{}1)^n$ for $ n \ge 0.$ -/
theorem number_theory_82784 (a : ℕ → ℤ)
    (h₀ : a 0 = 91)
    (h₁ : ∀ n, a (n + 1) = 10 * a n + (-1) ^ n) :
    ¬∃ n, ∃ m, a n = m ^ 2 := by

informal_statement: Solve the equation $\tan x = 2012^{\cos \left(x + \frac{\pi}{4}\right)}$ for $x$. Consider the behavior of the functions involved and determine all possible solutions within the interval $[0, 2\pi]$, and then generalize the solutions for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Solve the equation $\tan x = 2012^{\cos \left(x + \frac{\pi}{4}\right)}$ for $x$. Consider the behavior of the functions involved and determine all possible solutions within the interval $[0, 2\pi]$, and then generalize the solutions for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$. -/
theorem algebra_907 :
    {x : ℝ | tan x = 2012 ^ cos (x + π / 4) ∧ x ∈ Icc 0 (2 * π)} =
    {4.70765681} := by

soln_description:
Solution. $A$ and $C$ meet every 7 minutes, and $A$ and $B$ meet every 53 minutes. Therefore, all three will meet at a time that is a multiple of both 7 and 53, which is $7 \cdot 53=371$ minutes.

Criteria. If 53 minutes is replaced with 46 - 3 points. Solved by trial with lengths and speeds -1 point. Only the answer without explanation - 0 points.
informal_statement: 7. Three cars $A, B$ and $C$ start simultaneously from the same point on a circular track. $A$ and $B$ drive clockwise, while $C$ drives counterclockwise. All cars move at constant (but pairwise distinct) speeds. Exactly 7 minutes after the start of the race, $A$ meets $C$ for the first time. After another 46 minutes, $A$ and $B$ meet for the first time. After how much time from the start of the race will all three cars meet for the first time?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7. Three cars $A, B$ and $C$ start simultaneously from the same point on a circular track. $A$ and $B$ drive clockwise, while $C$ drives counterclockwise. All cars move at constant (but pairwise distinct) speeds. Exactly 7 minutes after the start of the race, $A$ meets $C$ for the first time. After another 46 minutes, $A$ and $B$ meet for the first time. After how much time from the start of the race will all three cars meet for the first time? -/
theorem algebra_285405 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h1 : a ≠ b) (h2 : a ≠ c) (h3 : b ≠ c) (h4 : 7 / a = 7 / c + 46 / (a + b))
    (h5 : 7 / b = 7 / a + 46 / (a + b)) :
    7 / a = 371 / 60 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_285405 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h1 : a ≠ b) (h2 : a ≠ c) (h3 : b ≠ c) (h4 : 7 / a = 7 / c + 46 / (a + b))
    (h5 : 7 / b = 7 / a + 46 / (a + b)) :
    7 / a = 371 / 60 := by
  have h6 : a * b * c ≠ 0 := by
    positivity
  field_simp [show a ≠ 0 by positivity, show b ≠ 0 by positivity, show c ≠ 0 by positivity, show a + b ≠ 0 by nlinarith [show 0 < a by linarith [ha], show 0 < b by linarith [hb]]] at h4 h5 ⊢
  <;> nlinarith [sq_pos_of_ne_zero (sub_ne_zero_of_ne h1), sq_pos_of_ne_zero (sub_ne_zero_of_ne h2), sq_pos_of_ne_zero (sub_ne_zero_of_ne h3), mul_pos ha hb, mul_pos ha hc, mul_pos hb hc, sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (b - c), sq_nonneg (a - c)]

soln_description:
Prove that, as shown in the figure, on two adjacent sides of the square $ABCD$, segments $AE=a$ and $AF=b$ are taken respectively. Perpendiculars are drawn from these points to the sides, dividing the square into four rectangles, and $EG$ and $FH$ intersect at point $P$. Then $PA=\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}$,
$$
\begin{aligned}
PC & =\sqrt{(1-a)^{2}+(1-b)^{2}}, \\
PB & =\sqrt{(1-a)^{2}+b^{2}}, \\
PD & =\sqrt{a^{2}+(1-b)^{2}} ; AC=BD=\sqrt{2}.
\end{aligned}
$$
(1) If $P$ does not coincide with the center $O$ of the square, then $(PA$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
+PC)+(PB+ \\
PD)>AC+BD
\end{array}
$$
(2) If $P$ coincides with $O$, then $\left(PA+PC\right)$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
+(PB+PD)=AC \\
+BD. \text{ In any case, } PA
\end{array}
$$
$+PB+PC+PD \geq 2AC$, i.e., $\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}$ $+\sqrt{(1-a)^{2}+b^{2}}+\sqrt{a^{2}+(1-b)^{2}}$ $+\sqrt{(1-a)^{2}+(1-b)^{2}} \geqslant 2\sqrt{2}$ holds.

The original problem is an inequality proof problem, which demonstrates a "quantitative relationship." However, we solved the "quantitative relationship" using "geometric properties," which is a demonstration of flexible thinking. Flexibility refers to the adaptability and versatility of thinking. It is the key to divergent thinking, not only reflecting the amount of divergence but also showing the transformation of the direction of divergence (such as transforming "number" into "shape"). It already contains elements of "novelty," indicating the quality of divergent thinking. Flexibility is not only an extension of fluency but also a harbinger of uniqueness.

The "vertical connection" of knowledge, reflected in teaching, is a "progressive" process. Progressive advancement objectively shows the continuous development and change of "conditions" and "conclusions" in mathematical problems. Therefore, teachers should consciously seize the opportunity and guide students to strengthen the training of flexible thinking in the continuous development and change of conditions and conclusions.
informal_statement:
Example 2. Given: $0<a<1,0<b<1$. Prove:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
+\sqrt{a^{2}+(1-b)^{2}}+\sqrt{(1-a)^{2}+(1-b)^{2}} \\
\geqslant 2 \sqrt{2} . \\
\end{array}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Example 2. Given: $0<a<1,0<b<1$. Prove:
$$
\begin{array}{l}
+\sqrt{a^{2}+(1-b)^{2}}+\sqrt{(1-a)^{2}+(1-b)^{2}} \\
\geqslant 2 \sqrt{2} . \\
\end{array}
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_313833 (a b : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a ∧ a < 1) (hb : 0 < b ∧ b < 1) :
    sqrt (a^2 + (1 - b)^2) + sqrt ((1 - a)^2 + (1 - b)^2) ≥ 2 * sqrt 2 := by

soln_description:
The sufficiency is obvious. Now we prove the necessity. When $d=1$, $e_{j}=0(1 \leqslant j \leqslant s)$, the conclusion obviously holds. If $d>1$, then by $d \mid a$ and Theorem 1, we know that the prime divisors of $d$ must be among $p_{1}, \cdots, p_{s}$. Therefore, by Theorem 2, the standard factorization of $d$ must be
$$d=p_{1}^{e_{1}} \cdots p_{s}^{e_{s}} . \quad 0 \leqslant e_{j}, 1 \leqslant j \leqslant s .$$
informal_statement:
Proposition 3 Let $a$ be given by (2), then $d$ is a positive divisor of $a$ if and only if
$$d=p_{1}^{c_{1}} \cdots p_{s}^{e_{s}}, \quad 0 \leqslant e_{j} \leqslant \alpha_{j}, 1 \leqslant j \leqslant s .$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Proposition 3 Let $a$ be given by (2), then $d$ is a positive divisor of $a$ if and only if
$$d=p_{1}^{c_{1}} \cdots p_{s}^{e_{s}}, \quad 0 \leqslant e_{j} \leqslant \alpha_{j}, 1 \leqslant j \leqslant s .$$ -/
theorem number_theory_5923 {a d : ℕ} (hd : d ≠ 0) :
    d ∣ a ↔ ∃ s : ℕ, ∃ p : Fin s → ℕ, ∃ e : Fin s → ℕ,
      (∀ i, Nat.Prime (p i)) ∧
      (∀ i, e i ≤ a.factorization (p i)) ∧
      d = ∏ i, (p i) ^ (e i) := by

soln_description:
Solution: The inequality $b+c \geq 0$ gives $a+b+c \geq a$. On the other hand, adding up the other two given inequalities yields $(a+b)+(c+a) \geq 0$, resulting in $a+b+c \geq-a$. Since $|a|=a$ or $-a$, we have in any case that
$$
a+b+c \geq|a| \text {. }
$$

Similarly
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a+b+c \geq|b| \\
a+b+c \geq|c|
\end{array}
$$

Now adding these three inequalities and dividing by 3 yields the desired inequality.

Alt Solution 1: The previous solution used the symmetry of $a, b$, and $c$. We can also use that symmetry to assume without loss of generality that $a \geq b \geq c$.
If $b$ and $c$ are both negative, then so is $b+c$, which contradicts the given information. So there can be at most one negative value among the three, which with our ordering must be $c$.
In the case where $a, b$, and $c$ are all positive or 0 , then the positive (or zero) number $x=a+b+c$ is greater than or equal to $x / 3$.
Otherwise, since we have assumed that $c$ is the least of the three, $c$ is negative while $a$ and $b$ are not. Then $a+b+c=a+b-|c| \geq a$ since $b+c \geq 0$ tells us that $b \geq-c=|c|$. On the other hand $\frac{|a|+|b|+|c|}{3}=\frac{a+b-c}{3} \leq a$ since the average of three numbers is less than or equal to the greatest of the numbers. By transitivity we have $a+b+c \geq \frac{|a|+|b|+|c|}{3}$.

Alt Solution 2: The case where $a, b$, and $c$ are all positive or zero can be handled as before. For the case where $a, b \geq 0$ and $c<0, a+b+c-\frac{|a|+|b|+|c|}{3}=a+b+c-\frac{a+b-c}{3}=\frac{2 a+2 b+4 c}{3}=\frac{2(a+b)+2(b+c)}{3} \geq 0$.
informal_statement:
3 Suppose $a, b, c$ are real numbers such that $a+b \geq 0, b+c \geq 0$, and $c+a \geq 0$. Prove that
$$
a+b+c \geq \frac{|a|+|b|+|c|}{3} \text {. }
$$
(Note: $|x|$ is called the absolute value of $x$ and is defined as follows. If $x \geq 0$ then $|x|=x$; and if $x<0$ then $|x|=-x$. For example, $|6|=6,|0|=0$ and $|-6|=6$.)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3 Suppose $a, b, c$ are real numbers such that $a+b \geq 0, b+c \geq 0$, and $c+a \geq 0$. Prove that
$$
a+b+c \geq \frac{|a|+|b|+|c|}{3} \text {. }
$$
(Note: $|x|$ is called the absolute value of $x$ and is defined as follows. If $x \geq 0$ then $|x|=x$; and if $x<0$ then $|x|=-x$. For example, $|6|=6,|0|=0$ and $|-6|=6$.) -/
theorem inequalities_271373 (a b c : ℝ) (h₀ : a + b ≥ 0) (h₁ : b + c ≥ 0)
    (h₂ : c + a ≥ 0) :
    a + b + c ≥ (|a| + |b| + |c|) / 3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_271373 (a b c : ℝ) (h₀ : a + b ≥ 0) (h₁ : b + c ≥ 0)
    (h₂ : c + a ≥ 0) :
    a + b + c ≥ (|a| + |b| + |c|) / 3 := by 
  cases' abs_cases a <;> cases' abs_cases b <;> cases' abs_cases c <;> 
    all_goals
      nlinarith

informal_statement: Prove that for any positive integer $n$ the following identity holds $\frac{(2n)!}{n!}= 2^n \cdot (2n - 1)!!$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Prove that for any positive integer $n$ the following identity holds $\frac{(2n)!}{n!}= 2^n \cdot (2n - 1)!!$ -/
theorem number_theory_49189 (n : ℕ) (hn : n > 0) :
    Nat.factorial (2 * n) / Nat.factorial n = 2 ^ n * Nat.doubleFactorial (2 * n - 1) := by

informal_statement:
Let $f:[0,1] \to \mathbb{R}$ be a continuous function. Prove that there exists $\alpha \in [0,1]$ such that
$$\int_{0}^{1} f(x)x^2 \, dx = \frac{f(\alpha)}{3}.$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Real Complex TopologicalSpace Finset
open scoped BigOperators

/- Let $f:[0,1] \to \mathbb{R}$ be a continuous function. Prove that there exists $\alpha \in [0,1]$ such that
$$\int_{0}^{1} f(x)x^2 \, dx = \frac{f(\alpha)}{3}.$$ -/
theorem calculus_4455
  (f : ℝ → ℝ)
  (hf : ContinuousOn f (Set.Icc 0 1)) :
  ∃ α ∈ Set.Icc 0 1, ∫ x in (0)..1, f x * x ^ 2 = f α / 3 :=

soln_description:
Solution. a) Since \(m, n\) are natural numbers, the equality would imply \(\{m \sqrt{a}\} = \{-n \sqrt{a}\}\) ............................................................................................

Two numbers have the same fractional part only if their difference is an integer, hence \((m+n) \sqrt{a} \in \mathbb{Z}\), which is absurd ....................................................

b) Again by contradiction, let \(N\) be a non-zero natural number for which there exist non-zero and distinct \(m, n\) such that \(N = [m(a+\sqrt{a})] = [n(a-\sqrt{a})]\). Therefore,

\[
N \leq m(a+\sqrt{a}) < N+1, \quad N \leq n(a-\sqrt{a}) < N+1
\]

and the inequalities are strict because the terms in the middle are irrational .... 1 point

The inequalities can be rewritten as

\[
\frac{N}{a+\sqrt{a}} < m < \frac{N+1}{a+\sqrt{a}}, \quad \frac{N}{a-\sqrt{a}} < n < \frac{N+1}{a-\sqrt{a}}
\]

and by adding them,

\[
N \frac{2}{a-1} < m+n < (N+1) \frac{2}{a-1}
\]

............................................................................... 2 points

From here, \(N < \frac{a-1}{2}(m+n) < N+1\), which contradicts the fact that the number in the middle is an integer (\(a\) is odd) ............................................. 2 points

Observation. The problem can be considered as part of Beatty's theorem, which states that sets of the form \([n a]\) and \([n b]\) partition \(\mathbb{N}\) if and only if \(a\) and \(b\) are irrational and \(\frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b} = 1\).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Problem 2. Let $a$ be an odd natural number that is not a perfect square. Show that if $m$ and $n$ are non-zero natural numbers, then
a) $\{m(a+\sqrt{a})\} \neq \{n(a-\sqrt{a})\}$;
b) $[m(a+\sqrt{a})] \neq [n(a-\sqrt{a})]$. -/
theorem number_theory_100031 (a : ℕ) (ha : Odd a ∧ ¬ ∃ m, m^2 = a) (m n : ℕ) (hm : m ≠ 0) (hn : n ≠ 0) :
    Int.fract (m * (a + Real.sqrt a)) ≠ Int.fract (n * (a - Real.sqrt a)) ∧
    ⌊m * (a + Real.sqrt a)⌋ ≠ ⌊n * (a - Real.sqrt a)⌋ := by

soln_description:
1. Let \( a \) and \( b \) be two positive integers. We need to prove that the integer
   \[
   a^2 + \left\lceil \frac{4a^2}{b} \right\rceil
   \]
   is not a square. Here, \(\lceil z \rceil\) denotes the least integer greater than or equal to \( z \).

2. First, consider the cases where \( b = 1, 2, 4 \). For these values of \( b \), it is straightforward to verify that \( a^2 + \left\lceil \frac{4a^2}{b} \right\rceil \) is not a square. We will handle the case \( b = 3 \) separately, but for now, assume \( b > 4 \).

3. If \( b = 2b' \) is even, then we must have \( 2a^2 > b' \). If \( a = a_0 \) works, then \( a = (n - a_0)b' - a_0 \) also works. Suppose \( a_0 \) is the minimum working \( a \). Then we must have \( a_0 \leq (n - a_0)b' - a_0 \), which simplifies to \( 2a_0n \leq r < b \). This leads to a contradiction. Therefore, we can assume \( b \) is odd.

4. Set \( b + 2 = m \). We need to show that \( bn^2 - (b + 4)a^2 = r \) has no solutions in positive integers if \( 0 \leq r < b \). Assume the contrary, that \( (n, a) \) is a solution of \( bn^2 - (b + 4)a^2 = r \) such that \( n \) is minimal.

5. Consider the Pell's equation:
   \[
   x^2 - b(b + 4)y^2 = 1 \iff x^2 - (m^2 - 2)y^2 = 1
   \]
   It is easy to verify that \( (x_0, y_0) = \left( \frac{1}{2} m(m^2 - 3), \frac{1}{2} (m^2 - 1) \right) \) is a solution.

6. It is also verified that \( (x, y) = (|nx_0 - (m + 2)ay_0|, |nby_0 - ax_0|) \) is a solution of \( bx^2 - (b + 4)y^2 = r \). First of all, \( nx_0 \geq (m + 2)ay_0 \) because:
   \[
   \left( \frac{n}{a} \right)^2 = 1 + \frac{4}{m - 2} + \frac{r}{a^2(m - 2)} \geq \frac{m + 2}{m - 2} \geq \frac{(m^2 - 1)(m + 2)}{m(m^2 - 3)} = \frac{(m + 2)y_0}{x_0}
   \]

7. By the minimality of \( n \), it follows that:
   \[
   n \leq nx_0 - (m + 2)ay_0 = \frac{1}{2}(m(m^2 - 3)n - (m + 2)(m^2 - 1)a)
   \]
   which implies:
   \[
   n \geq \frac{a(m + 2)(m^2 - 1)}{m(m^2 - 3) - 2} = \frac{a(m - 1)(m + 2)}{(m - 2)(m + 1)}
   \]

8. Squaring and substituting \( n^2 = a^2 \left( 1 + \frac{4}{b} + \frac{r}{a^2b} \right) \), we obtain:
   \[
   1 + \frac{4}{m - 2} + \frac{r}{a^2(m - 2)} \geq \left( \frac{(m - 1)(m + 2)}{(m - 2)(m + 1)} \right)^2
   \]

9. Solving for \( a^2 \), we get:
   \[
   a^2 \leq \frac{r(m - 2)(m + 1)^2}{4(m + 2)} \implies a \leq \frac{b(b + 3)}{2\sqrt{b + 4}}
   \]

10. Obviously, \( n = \left\lceil a\sqrt{1 + \frac{4}{b}} \right\rceil \). Set \( x = \frac{4}{b} \). By the Taylor Series expansion:
    \[
    \sqrt{1 + x} = 1 + \frac{x}{2} - \frac{x^2}{8} + \cdots
    \]

11. Therefore:
    \[
    \left| \sqrt{1 + x} - \left( 1 + \frac{x}{2} \right) \right| \leq \frac{1}{8}(x^2 + x^3 + \cdots) = \frac{x^2}{8(1 - x)}
    \]

12. Hence:
    \[
    \left| a\sqrt{1 + \frac{4}{b}} - \left( a + \frac{2a}{b} \right) \right| \leq \frac{2a}{b(b - 4)} \leq \frac{b(b + 3)}{2\sqrt{b + 4}} \leq \frac{8}{\sqrt{b + 4}} < 1
    \]

13. So it follows that:
    \[
    n \in \left\{ \left\lceil a + \frac{2a}{b} \right\rceil, \left\lceil a + \frac{2a}{b} \right\rceil - 1 \right\}
    \]
    because \( \sqrt{1 + x} < 1 + \frac{x}{2} \).

14. Let \( \ell \) be the least non-negative integer such that \( b \mid 2a + \ell \). Remark that \( b \mid \ell^2 + r \). If \( n = a + \frac{2a + \ell}{b} \), then \( b \) comes out to be:
    \[
    -\frac{(2a + \ell)^2}{2a\ell - r}
    \]
    This forces \( r > 2a\ell \), but \( r - 2a\ell = \ell^2 + r - \ell(2a + \ell) \) is divisible by \( b \). Hence \( r - 2a \geq b \), but on the other hand \( r < b \). This is a contradiction.

15. Now for the second case, let \( \ell \) be the smallest non-negative integer such that \( n = a + \frac{2a - \ell}{b} \). Again, we remark that \( b \mid \ell^2 + r \). Putting this expression for \( n \) and solving for \( b \), we obtain:
    \[
    b = \frac{(2a - \ell)^2}{2a\ell + r}
    \]

16. Let \( 2a = bq + \ell \) where \( q \) is the quotient when \( 2a \) is divided by \( b \). Simplifying the above:
    \[
    q^2 - q\ell - \left( \frac{\ell^2 + r}{4} \right) = 0
    \]

17. Solving for \( q \), we get:
    \[
    q = \frac{1}{2}(b\ell \pm x)
    \]
    where:
    \[
    \ell^2 + 4\left( \frac{\ell^2 + r}{b} \right) = x^2
    \]

18. Now:
    \[
    \ell^2 < x^2 = \ell^2 + \frac{4(\ell^2 + r)}{b} < \ell^2 + \frac{4\ell^2}{b} + \frac{4r}{b} < \ell^2 + 4\ell + 4 \implies x = \ell + 1
    \]

19. Plugging in, we get \( 4 \mid 2\ell + 1 \), which is a contradiction. Therefore, the integer \( a^2 + \left\lceil \frac{4a^2}{b} \right\rceil \) is not a square.

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
Let $a$ and $b$ be two positive integers. Prove that the integer
\[a^2+\left\lceil\frac{4a^2}b\right\rceil\]
is not a square. (Here $\lceil z\rceil$ denotes the least integer greater than or equal to $z$.)

[i]Russia[/i]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a$ and $b$ be two positive integers. Prove that the integer
\[a^2+\left\lceil\frac{4a^2}b\right\rceil\]
is not a square. (Here $\lceil z\rceil$ denotes the least integer greater than or equal to $z$.)

[i]Russia[/i] -/
theorem number_theory_30946 (a b : ℕ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) :
    ¬ ∃ n, n^2 = a^2 + ⌈(4 * a^2 : ℝ) / b⌉ := by

soln_description:
6. (B).

From the given, we have $y=6-2 x$. Substituting into $u=4 x^{2}+3 x y+y^{2}-$ $6 x-3 y$, we get
$$
u=2 x^{2}-6 x+18 \text {. }
$$

And $x \geqslant 0, y=6-2 x \geqslant 0$, so $0 \leqslant x \leqslant 3$.
When $x=0$ or $x=3$, $u_{\text {min }}=18$.
informal_statement:
6. Let $x \geqslant 0, y \geqslant 0, 2x + y = 6$. Then the maximum value of $u = 4x^2 + 3xy + y^2 - 6x - 3y$ is ( ).
(A) $\frac{27}{2}$
(B) 18
(C) 20
(D) does not exist

Translate the above text into English, please keep the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 6. Let $x \geqslant 0, y \geqslant 0, 2x + y = 6$. Then the maximum value of $u = 4x^2 + 3xy + y^2 - 6x - 3y$ is ( ).
(A) $\frac{27}{2}$
(B) 18
(C) 20
(D) does not exist -/
theorem inequalities_315360 :
  IsGreatest {u | ∃ x y : ℝ, 0 ≤ x ∧ 0 ≤ y ∧ 2 * x + y = 6 ∧ u = 4 * x ^ 2 + 3 * x * y + y ^ 2 - 6 * x - 3 * y} 18 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

theorem inequalities_315360 :
  IsGreatest {u | ∃ x y : ℝ, 0 ≤ x ∧ 0 ≤ y ∧ 2 * x + y = 6 ∧ u = 4 * x ^ 2 + 3 * x * y + y ^ 2 - 6 * x - 3 * y} 18 := by
  constructor
  · -- Show that 18 is in the set.
    use 0, 6
    norm_num
  · -- Show that 18 is an upper bound.
    intro u h
    rcases h with ⟨x, y, hx, hy, h_eq, hu⟩
    have h1 : y = 6 - 2 * x := by linarith
    rw [h1] at hu
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 0), sq_nonneg (x - 3), sq_nonneg (x - 3 / 2), sq_nonneg (y), sq_nonneg (x - y), sq_nonneg (x + y - 3)]

soln_description:
Let at time $t$ (min) the first vessel contains $x$ (kg) of salt, and let in the subsequent small time interval $d t$ the amount of salt in this vessel decreases by $d x$.

During the time $d t$, $3 d t$ (l) of brine will flow out of the vessel. The concentration of the brine (the amount of salt in one liter of solution) at time $t$ will be $\frac{x}{100}(kg / l)$. If we assume that the concentration of the brine remains constant during the small time interval $d t$, then the amount of salt will decrease by $-d x=\frac{x}{100} \cdot 3 d t$ (since $d x<0$). Separating variables in this equation and integrating, we get

$$
\frac{d x}{x}=-\frac{3}{100} d t ; \ln x=-0.03 t+C_{1}
$$

From the initial condition $x=10$ when $t=0$, we determine the value of the constant $C_{1}=\ln 10$.

Therefore, the dependence of the amount of salt $x$ in the first vessel on time $t$ is expressed by the equation

$$
\ln x=-0.03 t+\ln 10 \text { or } x=10 e^{-0.03 t}
$$

Now let's find the dependence of the amount of salt $y$ on time for the second vessel. In the second vessel, the concentration of the brine at time $t$ is $\frac{y}{100}(kg / l)$. During the time $d t$, $3 d t(l)$ of brine will flow into it, containing $\frac{3 x}{100} d t$ (kg) of salt, and $3 d t$ (l) of brine will flow out, containing $\frac{3 y}{100} d t$ (kg) of salt, i.e., during the time $d t$ the amount of salt in the second reservoir will change by the amount

$$
d y=0.03 x d t-0.03 y d t \text { or } d y=0.03(x-y) d t
$$

Replacing $x$ in this equation with its expression from formula (3), we get a first-order linear equation

$$
d y=0.03\left(10 e^{-0.03 t}-y\right) d t ; y^{\prime}+0.03 y=0.3 e^{-0.03 t}
$$

the general integral of which has the form

$$
y=e^{-0.03 t}\left(C_{2}+0.3 t\right)
$$

The value of the constant $C_{2}$ is determined from the initial conditions; since $y=0$ when $t=0$, then $C_{2}=0$. Therefore, the dependence of the amount of salt $y$ in the second vessel on time $t$ is expressed by the equation

$$
y=0.3 t e^{-0.03 t}
$$

The sought moment of time, at which the amount of salt in both vessels will become the same, we find by setting $x=y$:

$$
10 e^{-0.03 t}=0.3 t e^{-0.03 t} ; 10=0.3 t ; t=33 \frac{1}{3} \text{ min}
$$

At this moment, there will be approximately $10 / e \approx 3.68$ kg of salt in each vessel.
informal_statement: 193. A vessel with a capacity of 100 liters is filled with brine containing 10 kg of dissolved salt. In 1 minute, 3 liters of water flow into it, and the same amount of the mixture is pumped into another vessel of the same capacity, initially filled with water, from which the excess liquid is drained. At what moment in time will the amount of salt in both vessels be the same?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 193. A vessel with a capacity of 100 liters is filled with brine containing 10 kg of dissolved salt. In 1 minute, 3 liters of water flow into it, and the same amount of the mixture is pumped into another vessel of the same capacity, initially filled with water, from which the excess liquid is drained. At what moment in time will the amount of salt in both vessels be the same? -/
theorem algebra_157519 (t : ℝ) (ht : t > 0) (h : 100 * t = 100 * (t - 1) + 3 * t) :
    t = 33 + 1 / 3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_157519 (t : ℝ) (ht : t > 0) (h : 100 * t = 100 * (t - 1) + 3 * t) :
    t = 33 + 1 / 3 := by
  linarith

informal_statement: Determine the largest integer $n$ such that $\frac{2008!}{31^n}$ is an integer.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Determine the largest integer $n$ such that $\frac{2008!}{31^n}$ is an integer. -/
theorem number_theory_8042 : IsGreatest {n | ∃ k : ℕ, Nat.factorial 2008 / (31 ^ n) = k} 66 := by

soln_description:
Solution. Let $x, y$ be the speeds of the athletes, $z$ be the length of the running track. According to the conditions of the problem,

$\left\{\begin{array}{l}\frac{z}{y}-\frac{z}{x}=a, \\ \frac{z}{x-y}=b\end{array} \Leftrightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}\frac{z}{y}-\frac{z}{x}=a \\ \frac{x}{z}-\frac{y}{z}=\frac{1}{b} .\end{array}\right.\right.$

Let $\frac{x}{z}=w, \frac{y}{z}=t$. Then

$\left\{\begin{array}{l}\frac{1}{b} \cdot \frac{1}{t w}=a, \\ w-t=\frac{1}{b}\end{array} \Leftrightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{l}\frac{1}{a b}=t w, \\ \frac{1}{b}=w-t\end{array} \Rightarrow t^{2}+t \cdot \frac{1}{b}-\frac{1}{a b}=0 \Rightarrow\right.\right.$

$\Rightarrow t=\frac{\sqrt{a^{2}+4 a b}-a}{2 a b}, w=\frac{\sqrt{a^{2}+4 a b}+a}{2 a b} \Rightarrow t+w=\frac{\sqrt{a^{2}+4 a b}}{a b} \Rightarrow$

$\Rightarrow \frac{a b}{\sqrt{a^{2}+4 a b}}=\frac{1}{t+w}=\frac{z}{x+y}$, where $\frac{z}{x+y}$ is exactly the time it takes for

the athletes to meet if they run in opposite directions.

Answer: $\frac{a b}{\sqrt{a^{2}+4 a b}} \mathrm{c}$.
informal_statement: 13.432 Two athletes are running on a closed track of a stadium. The speed of each is constant, but the first one takes $a$ seconds less to run the entire track than the second one. If they start running from a common starting point in the same direction, they meet every $b$ seconds. How long will it take for them to meet if they run in opposite directions on the same track at the same speeds?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 13.432 Two athletes are running on a closed track of a stadium. The speed of each is constant, but the first one takes $a$ seconds less to run the entire track than the second one. If they start running from a common starting point in the same direction, they meet every $b$ seconds. How long will it take for them to meet if they run in opposite directions on the same track at the same speeds? -/
theorem algebra_199720 (a b : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) :
    1 / a - 1 / b = 1 / (a * b / (2 * (a ^ 2 + 4))) := by

soln_description:
Let $f(x)=a_{0}+a_{1} x+a_{2} x^{2}+\cdots+a_{n} x^{n}+\cdots$
Then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
-2 x f(x)=-2 a_{0} x-2 a_{1} x^{2}-\cdots-2 a_{n-1} x^{n}+\cdots \\
-3 x^{2} f(x)=-3 a_{0} x^{2}-\cdots-3 a_{n-2} x^{n}+\cdots \\
-\frac{1}{1-3 x}=-1-3 x-3^{2} x^{2}-\cdots-3^{n} x^{n}+\cdots
\end{array}
$$

Adding the above four equations and using the given conditions, we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left(1-2 x-3 x^{2}\right) f(x)-\frac{1}{1-3 x}=-2, \\
f(x)=\frac{6 x-1}{(1+x)(1-3 x)^{2}}=\frac{A}{1+x}+\frac{B}{1-3 x}+\frac{C}{(1-3 x)^{2}} .
\end{array}
$$

Then
$$
\begin{array}{l}
A=\left.f(x)(1+x)\right|_{x \rightarrow-1}=-\frac{7}{16}, C=\left.f(x)(1-3 x)^{2}\right|_{x=\frac{1}{3}}=\frac{3}{4}, \\
0=\lim _{x \rightarrow+\infty} x f(x)=\lim _{x \rightarrow+\infty}\left[\frac{A x}{1+x}+\frac{B x}{1-3 x}+\frac{C x}{(1-3 x)^{2}}\right]=A-\frac{1}{3} B,
\end{array}
$$

So $B=3 A=-\frac{21}{16}$, thus
$$
\begin{array}{l} 
f(x)=-\frac{7}{16(1+x)}-\frac{21}{16(1-3 x)}+\frac{3}{4(1-3 x)^{2}} \\
=-\frac{7}{16} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{n} x^{n}-\frac{21}{16} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} 3^{n} x^{n}+\frac{3}{4} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} C_{n+1}^{1} 3^{n} x^{n} \\
=\sum_{n=4}^{\infty}\left[\frac{(4 n-3) \cdot 3^{n+1}-(-1)^{n} \cdot 7}{16}\right] x^{n}, \\
\text { Hence } a_{n}=\frac{1}{16}\left[(4 n-3) \cdot 3^{n+1}-(-1)^{n} \cdot 7\right] .
\end{array}
$$
informal_statement: Example 16 Given $a_{0}=-1, a_{1}=1, a_{n}=2 a_{n-1}+3 a_{n-2}+3^{n}(n \geqslant 2)$, find $a_{n}$.
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_222020 {a : ℕ → ℝ} (ha0 : a 0 = -1) (ha1 : a 1 = 1)
    (han : ∀ n ≥ 2, a n = 2 * a (n - 1) + 3 * a (n - 2) + 3 ^ n) :
    ∀ n, a n = ((4 * n - 3) * 3 ^ (n + 1) - (-1) ^ n * 7) / 16 := by
  intro n
  induction' n using Nat.strongRec with n ih
  cases n with
  | zero =>
    rw [ha0]
    norm_num
  | succ n =>
    cases n with
    | zero =>
      rw [ha1]
      norm_num
    | succ n =>
      have h1 := ih (n + 1) (by linarith)
      have h2 := ih (n) (by linarith)
      have h3 : a (n + 2) = 2 * a (n + 1) + 3 * a n + 3 ^ (n + 2) := by
        specialize han (n + 2) (by linarith)
        simp [show n + 2 - 1 = n + 1 by omega, show n + 2 - 2 = n by omega] at han ⊢
        linarith
      rw [h3]
      simp [h1, h2]
      field_simp
      ring_nf

soln_description:
The left most digit of an integer of length 2000 digits is 3 . In this integer, any two consecutive digits must be divisible by 17 or 23 . The 2000th digit may be either ' $a$ ' or ' $b$ '. What is the value of $a+b$ ?
(A) 3
(B) 7
(C) 4
(D) 10
(E) 17

## Solution

We start by noting that the two-digit multiples of 17 are $17,34,51,68$, and 85 . Similarly we note that the two-digit multiples of 23 are $23,46,69$, and 92 . The first digit is 3 and since the only two-digit number in the two lists starting with 3 is 34 , the second digit is 4 . Similarly the third digit must be 6 . The fourth digit, however, can be either 8 or 9 . Let's consider this in two cases.

## Case 1

If the fourth digit is 8 , the number would be 3468517 and would stop here since there isn't a number in the two lists starting with 7.

## Case 2

If the fourth digit is 9 , the number would be $346923469234 \ldots$ and the five digits ' 34692 ' would continue repeating indefinitely as long as we choose 9 to follow 6 .

If we consider a 2000 digit number, its first 1995 digits must contain 399 groups of ' 34692 '. The last groups of five digits could be either 34692 or 34685 which means that the 2000th digit may be either 2 or 5 so that $a+b=2+5=7$.

ANSWER: (B)
informal_statement:
The left most digit of an integer of length 2000 digits is 3. In this integer, any two consecutive digits must be divisible by 17 or 23 . The 2000th digit may be either ' $a$ ' or ' $b$ '. What is the value of $a+b$ ?
(A) 3
(B) 7
(C) 4
(D) 10
(E) 17
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The left most digit of an integer of length 2000 digits is 3. In this integer, any two consecutive digits must be divisible by 17 or 23 . The 2000th digit may be either ' $a$ ' or ' $b$ '. What is the value of $a+b$ ?
(A) 3
(B) 7
(C) 4
(D) 10
(E) 17 -/
theorem number_theory_276515 (n : ℕ) (h₀ : n > 0) (h₁ : (Nat.digits 10 n).length = 2000)
    (h₂ : (Nat.digits 10 n).headI = 3) (h₃ : ∀ i, 17 ∣ (Nat.ofDigits 10 [(Nat.digits 10 n)[i]!, (Nat.digits 10 n)[i + 1]!]) ∨
    23 ∣ (Nat.ofDigits 10 [(Nat.digits 10 n)[i]!, (Nat.digits 10 n)[i + 1]!])) :
    (Nat.digits 10 n)[1999]! + (Nat.digits 10 n)[1999 + 1]! = 7 := by

soln_description:
3. $10^{7}$

Solution: Both leading numbers $a, c$ are positive integers, $|1-a|$ is a non-negative integer, and from the given information, we deduce that $\sqrt{c-4}$ is also a non-negative integer. Therefore, we have
( I ) $\left\{\begin{array}{l}|1-a|=1 \\ \sqrt{c-4}=0\end{array}\right.$ or ( II) $\left\{\begin{array}{l}|1-a|=0 \\ \sqrt{c-4}=1 .\end{array}\right.$
Solving ( I ) yields $\left\{\begin{array}{l}a=2 \\ c=4\end{array}\right.$ or $\left\{\begin{array}{l}a=0 \\ c=4\end{array}\right.$ (discard).
Solving ( II ) yields $\left\{\begin{array}{l}a=1 \\ c=5\end{array}\right.$.
Thus, $a+c=6, \lg (x y)=\lg x+\lg y=a+b+c+d=7$,
Therefore, $x y=10^{7}$.
informal_statement: 3. Given that $x$ and $y$ are real numbers greater than 10, the characteristic of $\lg x$ is $a$, and the mantissa is $b$; the characteristic of $\lg y$ is $c$, and the mantissa is $d$, and $|1-a|+\sqrt{c-4}=1$, $b+d=1$, then $x y=$ $\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. Given that $x$ and $y$ are real numbers greater than 10, the characteristic of $\lg x$ is $a$, and the mantissa is $b$; the characteristic of $\lg y$ is $c$, and the mantissa is $d$, and $|1-a|+\sqrt{c-4}=1$, $b+d=1$, then $x y=$ $\qquad$ -/
theorem algebra_162213 {x y : ℝ} (hx : x > 10) (hy : y > 10)
    (a b c d : ℝ) (ha : a = ⌊Real.logb 10 x⌋) (hb : b = Real.logb 10 x - a)
    (hc : c = ⌊Real.logb 10 y⌋) (hd : d = Real.logb 10 y - c)
    (h1 : |1 - a| + Real.sqrt (c - 4) = 1) (h2 : b + d = 1) :
    x * y = 10 ^ 7 := by

informal_statement:
If $a$ and $b$ are integers such that $a > b$ and $\sqrt{8 - \sqrt{60}} = \sqrt{a} - \sqrt{b}$, find the value of $a - b$.

If $a$ and $b$ are integers such that $a > b$ and $\sqrt{8 - \sqrt{60}} = \sqrt{a} - \sqrt{b}$, find the value of $a - b$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If $a$ and $b$ are integers such that $a > b$ and $\sqrt{8 - \sqrt{60}} = \sqrt{a} - \sqrt{b}$, find the value of $a - b$.

If $a$ and $b$ are integers such that $a > b$ and $\sqrt{8 - \sqrt{60}} = \sqrt{a} - \sqrt{b}$, find the value of $a - b$. -/
theorem algebra_5088 {a b : ℤ} (h : a > b) (h' : Real.sqrt (8 - Real.sqrt 60) = Real.sqrt a - Real.sqrt b) :
    a - b = 2 := by

soln_description:
# Answer: 6

Solution: Example: one boy collected 10 apples, the rest collected 2 each, totaling 20.

Evaluation: Let's prove that there could not have been fewer boys. We know that $10\%$ of the total number of apples is an integer, let's denote it as $k$. Suppose $n$ people collected ten apples each, and $m$ people collected $10\%$ each, then $10n = (10-m)k$, which means $10n$ is divisible by $10-m$. When $m=1$ or $m=3$, we get that $10n$ is divisible by 9 or 7, respectively, meaning $n$ is divisible by 9 or 7, which is too large. When $m=2$ or $m=4$, we get that $10n$ is divisible by 8 or 6, respectively, meaning $n$ is divisible by 4 or 3, and $m+n \geqslant 6$. When $m \geqslant 5$, the total number of boys is at least 1 more, meaning, again, at least 6.
informal_statement: 2. (2 points) Boys were collecting apples. Each collected either 10 apples or $10\%$ of the total number of apples collected, and there were both types. What is the smallest number of boys there could have been?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. (2 points) Boys were collecting apples. Each collected either 10 apples or $10\%$ of the total number of apples collected, and there were both types. What is the smallest number of boys there could have been? -/
theorem number_theory_218135 {n : ℕ} (hn : n > 0) (h : ∃ x y, x * 10 + y * (x + y) / 10 = n * 10) :
    n ≥ 6 := by

informal_statement:
Let $x, y, z \geq 0$ such that $x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = 1$. Prove that
\[ \frac{x}{1-x^2} + \frac{y}{1-y^2} + \frac{z}{1-z^2} \geq \frac{3\sqrt{3}}{2}. \]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib
open Real

/- Let $x, y, z \geq 0$ such that $x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = 1$. Prove that
\[ \frac{x}{1-x^2} + \frac{y}{1-y^2} + \frac{z}{1-z^2} \geq \frac{3\sqrt{3}}{2}. \] -/
theorem inequalities_8341
    (x y z : ℝ)
    (hx : 0 ≤ x)
    (hy : 0 ≤ y)
    (hz : 0 ≤ z)
    (h : x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = 1) :
    3 * sqrt 3 / 2 ≤ x / (1 - x^2) + y / (1 - y^2) + z / (1 - z^2) := by

informal_statement:
Given that $x$ is a real number, find the maximum value of $ \sqrt { x - 12 } + \sqrt { 30 - x } $.

Given that $x$ is a real number, find the maximum value of $ \sqrt { x - 12 } + \sqrt { 30 - x } $.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Given that $x$ is a real number, find the maximum value of $ \sqrt { x - 12 } + \sqrt { 30 - x } $.

Given that $x$ is a real number, find the maximum value of $ \sqrt { x - 12 } + \sqrt { 30 - x } $. -/
theorem algebra_4927 (x : ℝ) (hx : x ≤ 30 ∧ x ≥ 12) :
    sqrt (x - 12) + sqrt (30 - x) ≤ 6 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real

theorem algebra_4927 (x : ℝ) (hx : x ≤ 30 ∧ x ≥ 12) :
    sqrt (x - 12) + sqrt (30 - x) ≤ 6 := by

  have h1 : x - 12 ≥ 0 := by linarith [hx.right]
  have h2 : 30 - x ≥ 0 := by linarith [hx.left]
  
  have h3 : sqrt (x - 12) ^ 2 = x - 12 := Real.sq_sqrt (by linarith)
  have h4 : sqrt (30 - x) ^ 2 = 30 - x := Real.sq_sqrt (by linarith)
  
  have h5 : sqrt (x - 12) ^ 2 + sqrt (30 - x) ^ 2 = 18 := by 
    rw [h3, h4]
    linarith
  
  nlinarith [sq_nonneg (sqrt (x - 12) - sqrt (30 - x)), sq_nonneg (sqrt (x - 12) + sqrt (30 - x)), Real.sqrt_nonneg (x - 12), Real.sqrt_nonneg (30 - x), Real.sq_sqrt (show (x - 12) ≥ 0 by linarith), Real.sq_sqrt (show (30 - x) ≥ 0 by linarith)]

soln_description:
15. Suppose $p=q$. Substituting we get $p^{2}(2-n)=1$ which is impossible because 1 is not divisible by any prime. Therefore, $p$ and $q$ must be different; since the equation is symmetric in $p$ and $q$ we can assume that $q>p$, i.e., $q \geq p+1$. Let's now write our equation as:

$$
p^{2}-1=p q n-q^{2}=q(p n-q) \text {. }
$$

This means that $p^{2}-1$ is a multiple of $q$ and thus $q$ is a prime divisor of $p^{2}-1$. Therefore,

$$
q \mid p^{2}-1=(p-1)(p+1) .
$$

Now, since $q$ is a prime number, it must be present either in the factorization of $p-1$ or in that of $p+1$; in both cases $q \leq p+1$. By the initial assumption, we had $q \geq p+1$ and thus we get that $q=p+1$. Among two consecutive numbers, one must necessarily be even and therefore is 2 (the only even prime) and the other is necessarily 3 since 1 is not prime. Now let's check if the equation can be solved for $n$ by substituting $p=2$ and $q=3$:

$$
4+9=6 n+1,
$$

from which $n=2$. The only two solutions are therefore $(2,3,2)$ and $(3,2,2)$.
informal_statement:
## 15. ILLUSTRATIVE EXERCISE

Find all ordered triples of positive integers $(p, q, n)$ such that $p, q$ are primes and $p^{2}+q^{2}=p q n+1$.

SOLUTION
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## 15. ILLUSTRATIVE EXERCISE

Find all ordered triples of positive integers $(p, q, n)$ such that $p, q$ are primes and $p^{2}+q^{2}=p q n+1$.

SOLUTION -/
theorem number_theory_136561 (p q n : ℕ) (hp : p.Prime) (hq : q.Prime)
    (h : p > 0 ∧ q > 0 ∧ n > 0) :
    p^2 + q^2 = p * q * n + 1 ↔ (p = 2 ∧ q = 3 ∧ n = 2) ∨ (p = 3 ∧ q = 2 ∧ n = 2) := by

informal_statement: The sequence $\{x_n\}_{n\ge1}$ is defined by $x_1 = 7$, $x_{n+1} = 2x^2_n - 1$, for all positive integers $n$. Prove that for all positive integers $n$ the number $x_n$ cannot be divisible by $2003$.

import Mathlib

/- The sequence $\{x_n\}_{n\ge1}$ is defined by $x_1 = 7$, $x_{n+1} = 2x^2_n - 1$, for all positive integers $n$. Prove that for all positive integers $n$ the number $x_n$ cannot be divisible by $2003$. -/
theorem number_theory_41857 (x : ℕ → ℤ) (hx1 : x 1 = 7)
    (hxn : ∀ n > 0, x (n + 1) = 2 * (x n)^2 - 1) :
    ∀ n > 0, ¬ 2003 ∣ x n := by

theorem number_theory_7143 : ¬ ∃ b : ℚ, ∀ r : ℚ, r ∈ {x | x ^ 2 < 2} → b ≤ r := by

informal_statement: Prove that every positive rational number can be represented in the form $\dfrac{a^{3}+b^{3}}{c^{3}+d^{3}}$ where a,b,c,d are positive integers.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Prove that every positive rational number can be represented in the form $\dfrac{a^{3}+b^{3}}{c^{3}+d^{3}}$ where a,b,c,d are positive integers. -/
theorem number_theory_36865 (q : ℚ) (hq : q > 0) :
    ∃ a b c d : ℕ, a > 0 ∧ b > 0 ∧ c > 0 ∧ d > 0 ∧ q = (a^3 + b^3) / (c^3 + d^3) := by

soln_description: We can once again apply IAG in this exercise: $\sqrt[n]{n!}=$ $\sqrt[n]{1 \times 2 \times \ldots \times n} \leq \frac{1+2+\ldots+n}{n}=\frac{n+1}{2}$, hence the required inequality.
informal_statement:
Let $n \geq 1$ be an integer. Show that:

$$
n!\leq\left(\frac{n+1}{2}\right)^{n}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Nat

/- Let $n \geq 1$ be an integer. Show that:

$$
n!\leq\left(\frac{n+1}{2}\right)^{n}
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_136530 {n : ℕ} (hn : 1 ≤ n) :
    n ! ≤ ((n + 1) / 2 : ℝ) ^ n := by

soln_description:
$$
s=\frac{b}{2} t^{2}, \quad s=\frac{c}{\cos \alpha}, \quad \text { also } \quad \frac{c}{\cos \alpha}=\frac{b}{2} t^{2} \quad \text { or } \quad t=\sqrt{\frac{2 c}{b \cos \alpha}}
$$

From the last equation, the acceleration $b$ still needs to be eliminated. From $F=m b$ it follows that $b=\frac{F}{m}$ and since $F=G-\sin \alpha$ and $G=g \cdot m$, we get $b=g \cdot \sin \alpha$. Therefore, using an addition theorem,

$$
t=\sqrt{\frac{2 c}{g \cdot \sin \alpha \cos \alpha}}=\sqrt{\frac{4 c}{g \cdot \sin (2 \alpha)}}
$$

The time $t$ should assume a minimum value; this is exactly the case when the denominator of the fraction under the square root assumes a maximum value, i.e., when $\sin (2 \alpha)=1$. This immediately yields

$$
\alpha=45^{\circ} ; \quad t_{\min }=\sqrt{\frac{4 c}{g}}=2 \sqrt{\frac{c}{g}}
$$
